title: Spoken By the Other EP
label: XL
description: The mischievous electronic producer teams up with the photographer on an album where the latter’s voice becomes the source material for unsettling tracks full of silence and space.

title: Magnetic Memory
label: Don Giovanni
description: The Anti-Pop Consortium rapper and producer imagines the death of hip-hop as a means for exploring histories both personal and political: “To write like it’s the afterlife.”

title: Some Rap Songs
label: Tan Cressida
description: With his latest record, the onetime teen prodigy reemerges as the face of a new sound and scene that blurs the line between avant-garde jazz and hip-hop.

title: Anne
label: Western Vinyl
description: On his second solo album, the saxophonist and Destroyer collaborator grapples with intergenerational trauma by turning interviews with his mother into gorgeous and empathetic ambient music.

title: The Dream My Bones Dream
label: Drag City
description: Again working with producer Jim O’Rourke, the Japanese singer/songwriter explores a peculiar family history in songs that pull her own musical past into the present.

title: Look Now Look Again
label: Polyvinyl
description: A timely reissue of this prescient Midwest emo band’s back catalog—including their second and best album—shows how they transformed sadness into searching euphoria.

title: “Ouch”
label: Tin Angel
description: The Vancouver singer-songwriter lays everything bare on his latest record.

title: A Brief Inquiry Into Online Relationships
label: Dirty Hit
description: The British band’s outrageous and eclectic third album attests to the worth of putting in an honest effort in the face of near-constant gloom.

title: Daily Routine
label: Peder Mannerfelt Produktion
description: On his most extreme and cohesive solo album yet, the Swedish producer and Fever Ray collaborator steers from the dancefloor while locating a sense of humor within techno.

title: Creed II: The Album
label: Eardruma
description: Whereas the first Creed soundtrack reached for the rafters, the sequel is placeless and tame. Its only muse seems to be Mike WiLL’s contact list.

title: G I R L C O D E
label: Quality Control
description: The Miami duo’s new album builds on the strengths of their recent mixtape with speaker-rattling songs about pleasure, power, and strong women unapologetically getting their own way.

title: Terminal
label: UIQ
description: The Cairo electronic linchpin at last combines his kinetic production and hip-hop acumen in quick blasts that delightfully warp the words of some of Egypt’s best rappers.

title: The Fuzz EP
label: self-released
description: Linnea Siggelkow downsized her city of choice, a move that inspired her to confront confusion and ambivalence in six dream-pop gems that carve out a welcome space of security.

title: Moriyama EP
label: Palto Flats
description: The Japanese footwork producer largely steps away from the genre on this five-track EP, exploring an illusion of motion through a woozy sense of space and stillness.

title: Fever Focus EP
label: LuckyMe
description: After last year’s Feel Infinite, the Canadian producer expands and refines his arsenal of club tools, folding touches of acid and ambient into tracks that build on his melodic sensibilities.

title: Shugga Sextape Vol. 1
label: UNO NYC
description: The latest mixtape from this brilliantly over-the-top R&B singer finds him mixing spirituality with salaciousness while creating a heavily Auto-Tuned space somewhere between T-Pain and SOPHIE.

title: Love in the Time of Lexapro EP
label: Warp
description: After the fantastical Age Of, Daniel Lopatin plays it relatively straight on this four-track EP, though reworks from Ryuichi Sakamoto and (Sandy) Alex G take his material in intriguing new directions.

title: The Lillywhite Sessions
label: Dead Oceans
description: On what may seem like a readymade gag, the psych-folk favorite covers the lost Dave Matthews Band album in full. He convincingly connects his adolescent love to his adult explorations.

title: Ghost Box (Expanded)
label: Northern Spy
description: After the Western soundscapes of their debut album took hold through Spotify, the New York quintet return with an expanded edition of their meditative, magnetic debut.

title: Acrylic
label: Hardcover
description: On her second album, the mysterious Brooklyn rapper begins to pull back the mask with vivid reporting about the trials and triumphs of her home and the resilience of black womanhood.

title: Moondance
label: Warner Bros.
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Van Morrison’s 1970 classic.

title: Ghost Forests
label: Three Lobed
description: On their debut collaboration, the acclaimed harpist and the Espers singer pull long songs and meditative moods taut by creating unexpected tangles.

title: Wham! Bang! Pow! Let’s Rock Out!
label: Alcopop!
description: After a seven-year absence, a band whose quest for rock’n’roll fame always mixed a piss-take with genuine aspiration return in charmingly humbled fashion.

title: Love & Work: The Lioness Sessions
label: Secretly Canadian
description: On this installment in a series of expanded reissues from the vaults of the late Jason Molina, love songs with raw nerves document a tender, transitional period in his career.

title: Caution
label: Epic
description: On her 15th album, the R&B singer celebrates her ultimate-diva status by sticking to her core pop-soul aesthetic, despite collaborators like Poo Bear, Dev Hynes, and Skrillex.

title: LillyAnna
label: Whatever
description: On her solo debut, the veteran songwriter turns from writing hits for Shawn Mendes and One Direction to establishing her own voice.

title: Grapetooth
label: Polyvinyl
description: These synth-pop goofs attempt to translate the fun of their intoxicating stage show into their debut record, but they mostly make effortlessness seem insincere.

title: Music Inspired by Illumination & Dr. Seuss’ The Grinch EP
label: Columbia
description: Tyler, the Creator goes green.

title: Delta
label: Gentlemen of the Road
description: Having shed the beardy affect and folksy shuffle, the band could now slip mostly unnoticed between Imagine Dragons and twenty one pilots, but their newly palatable sound could really use more quirks.

title: Sinner EP
label: self-released
description: The young rapper’s typically erratic nature is missing from his latest EP. Instead, he is just hurried and sluggish.

title: Superstition
label: Prosthetic
description: These belligerent North Carolinians epitomize the crossover vitriol of metal and punk in 2018 and help signal the crucially political personality of their label.

title: Lover Chanting EP
label: Ninja Tune
description: On their first-ever EP, the Swedish dance-pop band again aim for escapism while failing to realize that the format offers a chance for exactly that.

title: Shiny and Oh So Bright, Vol. 1 / LP: No Past. No Future. No Sun.
label: Napalm
description: The legends of ’90s alt-rock have reunited only to bring this puzzling, indecisive husk of an album into the world.

title: Negative Capability
label: Panta Rei
description: At the age of 71, the British singer who helped define rock-star redemption shares gorgeous and vulnerable self-portraits, shaped by an ace backing band that sometimes includes Nick Cave.

title: 2 Minute Drills EP
label: Play Runners Association
description: The rising Oakland rapper and the Connecticut-raised beatmaker team up for a short and ridiculously fun tape about football, talking shit, pimping, and more football.

title: Hellboy
label: self-released
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the definitive Lil Peep experience with his breakthrough 2016 mixtape.

title: Black Velvet
label: Dunham
description: A year after the soul singer’s death, the label that gave him a third chance collects his stray tracks, shaping a showcase for his incredible versatility.

title: Jazz in Detroit / Strata Concert Gallery / 46 Selden
label: BBE
description: A newly discovered live document from 1973 finds the bassist emerging from a hiatus and negotiating a tradition he helped build with the “new thing” he helped inspire but often doubted.

title: Cocoon Crush
label: Pan
description: With his second album, Berlin’s TJ Hertz leaves techno behind in favor of hyperreal sound design charged with a narrative sensibility.

title: Hated: 2008-2011
label: Sacred Bones
description: This 10th-anniversary collection gathers loose tracks from the band’s first four years, as they explored disparate genres and song structures amid the bedlam.

title: Sujud
label: Sublime Frequencies
description: In a departure from the airier meditations of 2017’s Brønshøj (Puncak), the Indonesian duo’s Sublime Frequencies debut explores an earthy fusion of doom and folk metal.

title: A Love Letter to You 3
label: 10K Projects
description: The Ohio rapper showcases the benefits of refining a long-running aesthetic while also revealing its main limitation: the looming sense that things are getting a bit stale.

title: Oxnard
label: Aftermath
description: The rapping, singing, and drumming polymath approaches the funk canon from a rap perspective, offering a wide-angle portrait of Los Angeles’ hedonistic landscape.

title: Towards the Shadow
label: Northern Spy
description: Channeling krautrock’s philosophical legacy along with its repetitive grooves, the Baltimore duo’s second album aims for nothing less than political and personal liberation.

title: I Can See My House From Here
label: New West
description: On two reissued albums and a sprawling collection of arguably finished songs, this Georgia band did everything you want great indie rock to do. Now, everyone has a chance to hear it.

title: Simulation Theory
label: Warner Bros.
description: On their eighth album, the trio again pivot to the present, using current affairs, pop culture tropes, and contemporary electronics to aim for Spotify omnipotence.

title: Eden
label: self-released
description: On the Chicago rapper’s second album of the year, she once again displays her uncanny talent to blend the real and the absurd, the cartoon and the corporeal.

title: Passion
label: Modern Love
description: Following 2016’s archival dives into early electronic music, the UK duo marries eerie abstraction to the club-ready rhythms of their Testpressing series with newfound fury.

title: Fetti
label: ESGN
description: The tape is a short, sweet, and potent mix, an example of the good that can happen when seasoned vets link up and operate under the radar and outside of the major label system.

title: Thought Gang
label: Sacred Bones
description: Between the end of “Twin Peaks” and filming its prequel, David Lynch and Angelo Badalamenti made a wild album of sinister spoken-word jazz, available at last.

title: Origins
label: Kidinakorner
description: The Las Vegas rock band’s fourth album is categorically soaring and sometimes pleasant, but it is so broad and hollow that it is difficult to feel anything these guys are feeling.

title: This Is My Dinner
label: Caldo Verde
description: Mark Kozelek’s latest diary entry of an album amounts to a rote and barely listenable slog of hackneyed impersonations, petty grievances, and prideful nostalgia.

title: Bought to Rot
artist: Laura Jane Grace & the Devouring Mothers
label: Bloodshot
description: The debut album from the Against Me! singer’s new side project doubles as a deserved break from her very public role as a trans ambassador, but the songwriting too often feels like rock-band karaoke.

title: Limpid as the Solitudes
label: Shelter Press
description: The duo’s second collaborative album is an enveloping matrix of sounds both familiar and unfamiliar—a form of ambient music that refuses to recede into the background.

title: Humble Pi
label: Stones Throw
description: The long-dormant rapper/producer Edan is coaxed out of hiding by Homeboy Sandman, one of rap’s most irreverent characters, for a short, playfully psychedelic album.

title: İstikrarlı Hayal Hakikattir
label: Glitterbeat
description: On an album whose title translates as “Consistent Fantasy Is Reality,” the Turkish singer pursues distant dreams of freedom in a fusion of contemporary rock and Turkish folk.

title: NOIR
label: Zero Fatigue
description: The second album from the Chicago MC is lighter and more fun than his debut, focusing on his incredibly versatile voice within a warm palette of sludgy R&B and neo-funk.

title: Elastic Days
label: Sub Pop
description: The return of Dinosaur Jr. as a trio forced the singer to find a new avenue for his softer side and acoustic explorations. His third album in that series arrives at perfectly refined folk-rock.

title: Poison Ivy
label: YEAR0001
description: After last year’s more than promising Stranger, it is difficult to regard the Stockholm rapper’s latest mixtape as anything but a step backward.

title: I Used to Know Her: Part 2 EP
label: RCA
description: After an auspicious debut in 2016, the young R&B enigma looks for ways outside of the sound that has become her trademark—and gets lost in the process.

title: Toxicity
label: American Recordings
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a slice of hyperactive, politicized nu-metal from 2001.

title: First Collection 2006 – 2009
label: Sub Pop
description: The box set collects the pure pleasures of Fleet Foxes’ early years including a smattering of B-sides and rarities that reveal the band’s long-running beatific spirit.

title: Don’t Think That
label: Bloc Nation
description: BlocBoy JB has a habit of starting or promoting things that become more popular than he is. This seven-song mixtape is his attempt to combat that.

title: SHuSH
label: BIIPBIIP
description: This unstable amalgam of kazoo squeal, vacuum cleaner whine, and defenestrated drums from the prolific Spanish producer mines a joyous sense of play and surrealistic wonder.

title: She Remembers Everything
label: Blue Note
description: After reckoning with her father’s legacy on recent records, the singer offers a vivid, complex portrait of life and the compromises and love that shape adulthood.

title: Queen of Golden Dogs
label: Tri Angle
description: Leaving behind the beats of his previous work, the Bristol producer takes up chamber instruments, choral arrangements, and digital mayhem on a dizzying album about the nature of the self.

title: Come Over When You’re Sober Pt. 2
label: AUTNMY
description: The first posthumous album from Lil Peep stands as an act of tribute and preservation for an artist whose legacy is still very fragile.

title: Poison
label: Epic
description: The New York producer’s second album is a showcase not only for the marquee guests but for Swizz’s talent as a great arranger and knowing when to step out of the way.

title: You Won’t Get What You Want
label: Ipecac
description: These hardcore miscreants never seemed like a band suited for reunions, so their first album in eight years reimagines their prior intensity with blown-out, abstracted menace.

title: Wild Yout EP
label: Alpha
description: The South East London rapper carves out a lane between grime and UK rap on an EP marked by industrial-strength 808s and her own playful bark.

title: Heart Shaped Bed
label: Crystal Math
description: No matter how much effort Dollanganger injects into her morose sixth album, little on here manages to dig past the surface.

title: OX
label: UMG
description: Strip away the cringe threats and drip talk and what’s left is a glorified beat tape that indicates that, artistically, Matt Ox has a ways to go to discover his sound.

title: El Mal Querer
label: Sony
description: The second album from the Spanish singer is a remarkable feat, seamlessly linking flamenco’s characteristic melodrama to the heart-wrenching storytelling of modern, woman-flexing R&B.

title: Two Houses EP
label: Young Turks
description: On his debut EP, the Kansas City singer-producer shows off both his extraordinary voice and his remarkable facility for wringing maximum sentiment out of the most negligible nonsense phrases.

title: Not All Heroes Wear Capes
label: Republic
description: The Atlanta producer returns with a guest-filled album that builds on and creates a bigger version of the dark, hard-hitting production that has turned him into rap’s definitive producer.

title: More Blood, More Tracks: The Bootleg Series Vol. 14
label: Columbia
description: Jokes about the title aside, this payload of alternate takes presents a complex portrait of a complicated time for the singer-songwriter as he made a masterpiece.

title: The Last Rocket
label: Quality Control
description: The solo debut from the least attention-hungry member of Migos proves what many have long suspected—he is the trio’s best rapper, with the most promising career prospects outside of the group.

title: No Tourists
label: BMG
description: On their seventh studio album, the UK rave veterans help themselves liberally to sounds and ideas from their back catalog while punching up the production to ultra-modern standards.

title: Lost EP
label: Lost Kids
description: Amid newfound success, the soulful Los Angeles singer voices the anxieties of growing up and meeting creative expectations during turbulent times.

title: White Bronco
label: EMPIRE
description: Working with a grab bag of producers, the once-hyperlocal rapper serves up cold lines that lack the pizazz of his best work—at least until an old favorite returns.

title: Overload
label: Brainfeeder
description: The restless avant-garde soul singer is still reinventing rhythm and blues for the future, now more than ever on the most pop-focused album of her prolific career.

title: Thresholder
label: Fat Cat
description: This compendium of odds and ends from the Canadian singer and sound artist may be his most incisive and convincing album yet, thanks to the way his voice finally becomes one with his machines.

title: Ultraviolet
label: Warp
description: The prepared-piano specialist abandons the meticulous compositions of her previous albums, editing down improvisations and bejeweling them with layers of synthesizers and effects.

title: Dionysus
label: PIAS
description: Pairing a world’s worth of traditional instruments with widescreen gestures, the legendary duo explore the myth of a Greek god in an unknown tongue.

title: Interstate Gospel
label: RCA Records Nashville
description: On their third album as a group, country singer-songwriters Miranda Lambert, Ashley Monroe, and Angaleena Presley offer full-blooded portraits of women who struggle, get revenge, and soldier on.

title: Supa Dupa Fly
label: EastWest
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Missy Elliott’s debut, a radically empathetic statement of self.

title: Crush Crusher
label: Hardly Art
description: After returning to solo status as a bandleader, Jilian Medford drops the spiky singing style that was her trademark, finding a softer delivery within the darkened corners of dream pop.

title: Alone at Last
label: Father/Daughter
description: On her quietly confident debut, this soulful Chicago singer-songwriter offers portraits of intimacy and songs about the need for self-love.

title: ...And Justice for All
label: Blackened Recordings
description: Written after the death of bassist Cliff Burton, Metallica’s infamously abrasive masterpiece gets its 30th-anniversary treatment at a time when its sociopolitical rumblings are painfully relevant.

title: MihTy
label: Def Jam
description: On their debut collaborative album, R&B’s most self-aware lotharios synthesize their respective approaches in quixotic pursuit of sexual healing.

title: LoVE me NOw
label: Mad Love
description: Tory Lanez sets the bar very, very high and he does not hit it. At all.

title: Salt
label: Twin Group
description: Inside songs that capture the body-moving pulse of nightlife and the post-club comedown, the Long Island quartet follow the danceable lead of their last album.

title: FM!
label: Blacksmith
description: On Vince Staples’ third album, the California rapper keeps it short and not so sweet.

title: Aviary
label: Domino
description: The Los Angeles musician’s fifth studio album is the most joyous, daring realization of her experimental tendencies yet: a sprawling, 90-minute search for meaning in a dehumanizing age.

label: Equal Vision
description: On the former emo standby’s first album in five years, Chris Conley documents the history of the band, missing the reason they mattered as he recalls his chart-topping glory days.

title: Premonitions
label: Terrible
description: On her gripping and redemptive debut, the Los Angeles singer seems bound for crossover status, with pop anthems that challenge power structures and embrace simple pleasures.

title: R.E.M. at the BBC
label: Craft
description: By bouncing among eras and albums, this enormous box set of sessions and broadcasts offers an elliptical, revisionist portrait of a band whose legacy is largely undecided.

title: Primary Progressive
label: Gobstopper
description: The British grime producer follows last year’s tender ode to fatherhood with a stark EP that attempts to come to terms with his father’s MS that is as inventive as it is vulnerable.

title: BALLADS 1
label: 88rising
description: Joji’s first full-length project features a host of guests in a quality effort to help push past the confines of his bedroom walls and tedious heartache.

title: Mona Lisa
label: Mello Music Group
description: Teaming up with a soulfully minded boom-bap producer, the Brooklyn rapper shapes a warmly nostalgic album around the core tenets of East Coast hip-hop.

title: Saturn
label: Little Tokyo
description: On her second album, the London singer-songwriter examines personal growth, romantic upheaval, and the trials of young adulthood through an astrological lens.

title: Deerhoof Plays Music of the Shining
label: Famous Class
description: Just in time for Halloween, the endlessly experimental and playful band take on two iconic pieces from The Shining and have a bit of frightful fun.

title: Pieces of a Man
label: Cinematic
description: Borrowing a title and sometimes a tone from Gil Scott-Heron, the Chicago rapper explores religion, consensual sex, and himself.

title: Halloween: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack
label: Sacred Bones
description: Just as he did for his 1978 film, John Carpenter provides the score for Halloween’s 2018 reboot. But this time, the synths have been cleaned up and dread is occasionally outweighed by winking nostalgia.

title: Siblings
label: Rvng Intl.
description: The New York/Berlin composer and choreographer’s second album explores creative collaboration as a means of creating family, particularly within the context of queer liberation.

title: If Only There Was a River
label: Woodsist
description: The California singer-songwriter’s first album is exquisitely rendered, a solemn display of restraint and loneliness.

title: Unreality
label: Dais
description: On her solo debut following the death of her Them Are Us Too partner, Kennedy Ashlyn navigates grief by sorting through echoes of 4AD’s essential early days and haunted goth textures.

title: Une Vie Cent Détours
label: My Bags
description: Prolific producer Charif Megarbane mixes symphonic soul, grainy funk, and old European film scores to offer a relatively concise glimpse into his wide musical world.

title: IC-01 Hanoi
label: ‎Jagjaguwar‎
description: Joined by his brother, father, and the Vietnamese musician Minh Nguyen, Ruban Nielson throws off his habitually weighty themes and digs into a refreshingly raw, heady session of psychedelic rock.

title: Universal Beings
label: International Anthem
description: The jazz drummer and producer’s hypnotic double album is culled from a year’s worth of gig tapes that he’s layered and spliced together into something wholly new and radically communal.

title: Car Wheels on a Gravel Road
label: Mercury
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the restless Southern spirit of Lucinda Williams’ fifth album.

title: Sonder Somatic
label: Hessle Audio
description: Blending UK bass, deconstructed techno, and abstract ambient, the Bristol producer crafts stripped-back club tracks distinguished by their crystalline sound design and icy atmospheres.

title: Suspiria (Music for the Luca Guadagnino Film)
label: XL
description: Luca Guadagnino’s remake of a horror classic features Yorke tackling a broader range of styles and ideas than any of his previous solo work, and all of them shine.

title: Arrive Without Leaving
label: Flying Moonlight
description: The career of the new age deity has been defined by a string of radiant collaborations. Here, with his longtime partner and a synth trio, he again lifts off.

title: Darker Days
label: Ingrid
description: The band’s eighth full-length is undoubtedly their strongest since Writer’s Block, with a renewed focus on eclecticism and sweet melodies.

title: Traversa
label: Ghostly
description: Ostensibly a side project to Will Wiesenfeld’s Baths, Geotic comes into its own on an album that treats background listening as a springboard into a world of color and texture.

title: 4AM Mulholland EP / After 4AM EP
label: FEENIIX RISING ENTERTAINMENT
description: On these two EPs, the R&B singer doesn’t simply revive her hit-making approach from the early 2000s; she uses her powerful voice to make the sounds of the moment her own.

title: boygenius EP
label: Matador
description: The sizable talent and personalities of Julien Baker, Phoebe Bridgers, and Lucy Dacus come together for a harmonious, confrontational, and all too brief EP.

title: 81b EP
label: Hinge Finger
description: This six-track EP from Peter O’Grady is moodier and more penumbral than anything he’s done before, with a much wider range of tempos and rhythm.

title: WRLD on Drugs
label: Epic
description: It’s a good effort to try and retrieve Future from the Pluto of his own imagination, but too often his collaboration with the 19-year-old Chicago rapper plays to neither of their strengths.

title: Bohemian Rhapsody OST
label: Virgin
description: Collecting the hits alongside parts of Queen’s rapturous 1985 Live Aid set, this soundtrack mirrors its movie in reflecting the band’s inability to move on.

title: Good to Feel
label: Triple B
description: Extending Richmond’s legacy of heavy weirdness, these upstarts flood hardcore with metal and noise references—all charged by a sense of revolutionary urgency.

title: Honey
label: Konichiwa
description: Robyn presents her first solo album in eight years subtly, with slight builds and light hands. But her masterful command of emotions on the dancefloor slowly reveals itself across another enthralling record.

title: Nuthin’ 2 Prove
label: Quality Control
description: The Atlanta rapper is a far better singer than he is a rapper, which is all too clear on his latest project.

title: Broken Politics
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: On her second consecutive album produced by Four Tet’s Kieran Hebden, the ever-adventurous former pop star takes on the moment’s social upheaval by getting personal.

title: The Anteroom
label: Domino
description: Tom Krell’s latest album of ambient R&B club music feels both reverent and relevant, with icy textures and knotty lyrics that leave plenty to untangle.

title: Songs of Love and Horror
label: Drag City
description: In conjunction with a hardcover collection of his lyrics, the singer-songwriter reimagines his classics and obscurities as intimate, acoustic tales.

title: Common Blah
label: Don Giovanni
description: For these alt-rock throwbacks about the causes and effects of bad relationships, it’s the unapologetic singing of Sonia Sturino that’s the secret weapon.

title: Warzone
label: Chimera
description: An endurance of idealism threads together these 13 reimagined protest songs, collected from four decades of albums. But their tempered presentation reveals a profound generational disconnect.

title: From the Series of Songs “Altogether Unaccompanied”
label: Luminelle
description: Across four short volumes, the Montreal singer-songwriter introduces a lonely and diverse set of songs written with an exceptional eye for melody and texture.

title: Anthem of the Peaceful Army
label: Lava
description: The debut from the young Michigan rock band is stiff, hackneyed, overly precious retro-fetishism.

title: Forever Neverland
label: Columbia
description: The Danish electro-pop chart-topper’s second album is dedicated to the quest for eternal youth; too often, though, her overbearing club songs merely kick against the onset of adulthood.

title: Us
label: Terrible
description: Where Lorely Rodriguez’s debut album brought a refreshing dose of weirdness to the crowded field of alt-pop R&B, her follow-up is more of an anodyne amalgam of 2018’s pop trends.

title: Stadium
label: Shelter Press
description: Inspired by a move into Manhattan, the adventurous drummer fuses worlds of avant-jazz and electronica in a dozen restrained pieces that feel like streetscape scores.

title: Pre Strike Sweep
label: In the Red
description: On their second album, this quartet featuring Ty Segall and Ex-Cult’s Chris Shaw prod and pull at their militaristic punk with psychedelic tricks and brief detours.

title: Remain in Light
label: Sire
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit an art-rock masterpiece, a thrilling synthesis of artifice and Afrobeat.

title: J.S. Bach: Six Suites for Viola Solo
label: ECM
description: In the hands of the master violist, this famous stretch of Bach’s music become body music, rooted in breath and wood and muscle.

title: Loving the Alien (1983-1988)
label: Parlophone
description: Bowie was never more popular during this period, one he looked back on with guilt and bile. But Loving the Alien offers a reset for listeners—to hear these albums fresh, liberated from their composer’s dismissive opinions.

title: First Flower
label: Captured Tracks
description: On her second album, the Austin singer-songwriter strengthens her voice and broadens her perspective, turning her gaze from romance to a more nuanced view of her own anxieties.

title: The Whole Thing Is Just There
label: Saddle Creek
description: On their best album, this fascinating “philosophy jam band” begins with indie rock touchstones and then explores the fringes of those ideas.

title: Last Building Burning
label: Carpark
description: Jaded, nihilistic, and heavy: Dylan Baldi leads his band into one of the most self-immolating and intense albums of his career.

title: A Wonderful Beast
label: K Records
description: With help from the Black Keys’ Patrick Carney and erstwhile pop star Michelle Branch, the DIY icon finds new ways to tease out light and dark, allure and anxiety with his key-ignoring baritone.

title: Suncity EP
label: Sony
description: The latest EP from the versatile young singer is a harmless taste of pop-inflected R&B, a style in which Khalid sounds largely unremarkable.

title: Treasure Hiding: The Fontana Years
label: Unknown
description: Collecting the sometimes-dismissed output of these pioneers between their masterpiece and their breakup, this box set sheds welcome light on how relevant many of these songs remain.

title: “A”
label: RCA
description: Usher and Zaytoven’s “collaborative project“ is a solid homage to the duo’s beloved Atlanta roots and the city’s sound that has permeated just about every corner of popular music.

title: QUAVO HUNCHO
label: Quality Control
description: The proper, widescreen debut from Quavo is filled with passable, professional songs that pale when compared to nearly any full-length Migos record.

title: The Light Is Leaving Us All
label: The Spheres
description: The latest from experimental musician David Tibet is an arduous but rewarding album, the feeling of listening to a preacher behind the pulpit, or a doomsayer on the soapbox.

title: Look Now
label: Concord
description: Joined by his Imposters in the studio for the first time in a decade, the silver-tongued songwriter turns tunes from abandoned musicals into a surprisingly cohesive record.

title: Black Dog in My Path
label: Double Double Whammy
description: The All Dogs leader adds a rock band behind much of her second solo album, but she somehow sounds more alone on those songs than on the record’s unflinching acoustic tunes.

title: Certainty Waves
label: Polyvinyl
description: After their longest break in a decade, the acoustic-and-drums duo return with hopes of reorienting their singular sound through the help of more electronics.

title: Fully Loaded
label: Glizzy Gang
description: The D.C. native takes a chip on his shoulder into the catchiest music of his career. In every Glizzy rap boast, you can hear in his voice all that was sacrificed to achieve it.

title: Bunny
label: Ghostly International
description: Though he recruits Tegan and Sara and a member of Protomartyr here, the producer’s voice emerges as the real star of these darkly funny, magnetic songs.

title: La Maison Noir
label: Roya
description: Once again taking up the mantle of the genre and social movement he calls “noirwave,” South Africa’s Yannick Ilunga finds new strength in personal expression and political engagement.

title: MassEducation
label: Loma Vista
description: With barely more than her voice and a piano, Annie Clark strips her hypersexual, neon-clad 2017 album Masseduction for parts. It is a welcome antidote to a career defined by cult and concept.

title: Time ‘n’ Place
label: Polyvinyl
description: On their sophomore album, the London trio animate songs about the complexity of memory and the promise of dreams with playful production choices and moments of bedlam.

title: Selva Oscura
label: Temporary Residence
description: Working remotely in Los Angeles and Brisbane, these two ambient mainstays toe the line for an album that exists in a perpetual state of becoming something else.

title: Songs of the Plains
label: Young Mary's
description: With his husky, sensitive baritone, this son of Canada’s Prairie Provinces mixes the tales of modern and historic wanderers on his second sterling album of traditional folk and country.

title: Jassbusters
label: Mexican Summer
description: The eccentric New Zealand singer-songwriter turns his skewed pop sensibilities toward soundtracking a five-part melodrama of his own making; it’s intermittently gorgeous but frustratingly foggy.

title: Ella Mai
label: 10 Summers
description: The perfectly fine debut from the London R&B singer offers a grip of retro, snappy jams without sounding like a pastiche.

title: [Untitled]
label: Run for Cover
description: The Philadelphia band’s seventh album draws from fiction, the history of international warfare, and their own internal rosary of images to create a dense, literary tangle of post-hardcore.

title: The B-52’s
label: Warner Bros.
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the debut from the B-52s, a bastion of provocative post-punk unlike anything else.

title: Empty Me
label: Double Double Whammy
description: On her second solo record, Gabrielle Herbst relishes pushing her voice to its limit.

title: Desperate Man
label: EMI
description: A year after headlining a night of the tragic Route 91 Harvest festival, the popular country renegade forgoes the obvious references on one of the most modest but poignant albums of his career.

title: Origami Harvest
label: Blue Note
description: Joining the Mivos Quartet’s strings with rapper Kool A.D. and a traditional jazz ensemble, the Oakland trumpeter crafts suite-like compositions that grapple with structural racism and state violence.

title: The Drought
label: Pan
description: Frederikke Hoffmeier’s voice is the thread that holds together her apocalyptic mood pieces, a cinematic take on noise that’s driven by dead-eyed focus.

title: abysskiss
label: Saddle Creek
description: The latest album from the Big Thief singer evokes a singular, solitary chill. With a great imagination for melody, Lenker conjures a world of mingled trauma and love.

title: Peaced and Slightly Pulverized
label: Trouble in Mind
description: Turning the gestures and feeling of classic rock into a statement on our modern malaise, this Omaha guitarist balances the tightness of a new band with the the rage of the day.

title: Bottle It In
label: Matador
description: The ranging album from the Philadelphia songwriter adopts a drifting mind as its emotional compass. There’s no rush to get where he’s going, and he rarely checks to see if you’re still following along.

title: Eternal Return
label: Relapse
description: The Richmond doom-metal quartet strips away the excess, honing in on a grunge and psych-rock core and letting Dorthia Cottrell shine as an extraordinarily compelling singer and bandleader.

title: Dime Trap
label: Grand Hustle
description: For the first time in years, the trap music co-architect sounds less like a copyright lawyer and more like a contributor to a culture he loves, even if he gets a little overzealous.

title: Vitriola
label: 15 Passenger
description: Working with a cellist and producer Mike Mogis for the first time in more than a decade, Tim Kasher’s angriest but most vulnerable band squares up against the era of Trump.

title: Drip Harder
label: Quality Control
description: Lil Baby and Gunna are one of the best new rap duos and their latest project develops a chemistry and brotherhood few others can lay claim to.

title: The Singles
label: Bikini Kill
description: Newly reissued on vinyl, Bikini Kill’s 1998 compilation stands as the defining document of the feminist punk band whose music remains relevant, righteous, and unflappably cool.

title: Fall Into the Sun
label: Merge
description: More like a eulogy for what was lost than a new chapter, Allison Crutchfield and Kyle Gilbride reunite for songs that document their lives since their breakup—and possibly chart a path forward.

title: C’est La Vie
label: Dead Oceans
description: For his first album in five years, Matthew Houck puts fatherhood and a move to Nashville to good use on songs that are sly and wry and allow his voice to cut through intricate arrangements.

title: Working Class Woman
label: Ninja Tune
description: The fourth album from the French Canadian producer explores the claustrophobic interior life of the club in frighteningly, sometimes comically deadpan detail.

title: MUDBOY
label: Cactus Jack
description: Sheck’s raw and unruly debut is a force to be reckoned with, the rare project from an über-hyped prospect that actually delivers on its promise.

title: A Star is Born Soundtrack
label: Interscope
description: At its peaks, the album delivers on the promise of its star-wattage with some of the most affecting and emotionally overwhelming pop songs of the year.

title: Bliss Signal
label: True Panther
description: A year after their onstage debut, the atmospheric black-metal artist WIFE and grime experimentalist Mumdance join again to fuse pummeling beats with sheets of noise into a kind of transcendent fury.

title: Plainly Mistaken
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: Mixing a deep knowledge of regional folk traditions with a delight in modern composition, the banjo player and his exploratory new trio are delightfully suspended between earth and outer space

title: Electric Messiah
label: eOne
description: The recent success of Matt Pike’s rebooted Sleep sounds like it’s rubbing off on his long-running High on Fire, whose 8th album leans on the heavier half of their habitual doom-meets-thrash mixture.

title: Dose Your Dreams
label: Merge
description: The art-hardcore band’s fifth album is a dynamic departure for the group, a long, psychedelic, concept-heavy odyssey that dips into many genres along the way.

title: Perfect Shapes
label: Carpark
description: On her second album, the sophisticated art-rock singer steps toward the center of her own songs, thanks in part to production from Wye Oak’s Jenn Wasner.

title: Embrya
label: Sony Music’s Certified Classics
description: The reissue of Maxwell’s second album from 1998 showcases the mercurial spirit that followed the R&B auteur down new, aqueous corridors.

title: AAARTH
label: Seradom Records
description: On their fourth album, the Welsh rockers build their towering songs on wobblier foundations for the sheer thrill of trying to make them topple.

title: Welcome 2 Detroit
label: BBE
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a piece of Detroit history that rippled through all of hip-hop.

title: Aru Otoko No Densetsu
label: Sun Ark
description: Moving away from footwork conventions and playing with a wider range of tempos, the Yokohama producer focuses his attention on a scintillating of tiny, tactile, and childlike sounds.

title: Beastland
label: Relapse
description: The industrial music and metal sculptures of Tristan Shone can sound and look scary. But there are songs and even soul lurking beneath the grim façade.

title: Island
label: shouting out loud!
description: A collaboration between the Japanese electronic artist and the Raincoats founding member lands at the natural middle of each musician's sensibilities.

title: Switched On / Refried Ectoplasm / Aluminum Tunes
label: Duophonic UHF Disks
description: Singles and splits documented a band’s between-albums evolution during the 1990s. These compilations, remastered and reissued, document that process for one of the era’s most innovative groups.

title: An American Treasure
label: Warner Bros.
description: This big box set marks the first posthumous release from the Petty estate and finds new meaning both through songs we thought we knew and necessary obscurities.

title: Wanderer
label: Domino
description: On her first album in six years, Chan Marshall roams the many moods of her songwriting with a careful, soft-spoken power.

title: WILKES
label: Leaving
description: Following up his collaboration with saxophonist Sam Gendel, the Los Angeles bassist returns with a dreamy album that dissolves jazz structures into ambient, vaguely psychedelic forms.

title: For My Crimes
label: Sacred Bones
description: On her moody eighth album, the Boston singer-songwriter examines the icy terrain of marital strife through the lens of her habitual gothic folk.

title: The Window
label: Mack Avenue
description: The leader of a new pack of fully modern jazz singers explores the historical context and modern possibilities of every song she sings, even the deepest American standards.

title: The Rick and Morty Soundtrack
label: Sub Pop
description: The acerbic, self-deprecating magic of the show barely translates to its soundtrack. Taken on their own, most of the original music is decent comedy rap, which is to say, imminently disposable.

title: Luca Brasi 3
label: Bread Winners’ Association
description: At last out of prison, the Louisiana rapper returns with his hard-hitting verses and endearing croon—and lots of new stories to share.

title: Young Sinatra IV
label: Def Jam
description: Over some dusty boom-bap, the undoubtedly talented Logic spends just way too much time trying to forcibly cement his place in hip-hop history.

title: Soul on Fire
label: self-released
description: This sloppy 15-minute freebie reaffirms that, no matter how many names he takes or projects he starts, the former half of Hype Williams is always half-interesting.

title: Aftering
label: Polyvinyl
description: The Michigan indie rocker’s final album in a trilogy is a despairing look at the world and the life of a songwriter told with great wit, melodies, and self-deprecation.

title: Hosono House/ Paraiso / Cochin Moon / Philharmony / omni Sight Seeing
label: Light in the Attic
description: Though his international esteem is virtually nonexistent, this Japanese polymath pioneered a musical ethic of open borders and freewheeling hybridity, epitomized by five new reissues.

title: Gangin II
label: SOB X RBE
description: Compared to the first Gangin, the Bay Area foursome is now more patient and ruminative. They tap deeper into a give-and-take dynamic that makes them one of rap’s most exciting groups.

title: Wild Wild Country (Original Score)
label: Western Vinyl
description: The score for this surprise Netflix hit about a religious community in rural Oregon revels in emotional indecision, asking you to choose the truth for yourself.

title: FABRICLIVE 100
label: Fabric
description: As one of the last sets in the long-running DJ series, FABRICLIVE 100 seems almost willfully perverse, a pointed attempt to upset notions of what Burial is really about.

title: Autobiography
label: Planet Mu
description: In her soundtrack to the choreographer Wayne McGregor’s DNA-inspired dance work, the post-footwork producer moves from her serpentine IDM toward a new style informed by ambient minimalism.

title: The Lamb
label: Hardly Art
description: On her second album, Lillie West retains the charming simplicity of her songs, but she finds new depth as a songwriter as she explores the act of standing up to herself.

title: Street Worms
label: YEAR0001
description: With theatrical élan, the Swedish rabble-rousers lampoon the masculine and the moneyed on songs that match parody with precision.

title: Tha Carter V
label: Young Money Entertainment
description: The long-delayed album captures Wayne how we want to remember him: openhearted, word-drunk, and exhilarated by the possibilities of his own voice.

title: Digital Garbage
label: Sub Pop
description: The Seattle scuzz-punk pioneers deliver a grave diagnosis of a festering societal condition.

title: (after)
label: P.W. Elverum & Sun
description: Captured during a festival set inside a 13th-century church in the Netherlands, this live album of songs about death allows listeners to revisit their private grief.

title: Maxwell’s Urban Hang Suite
label: Columbia
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a true R&B classic from 1996, the spacious and grooving debut from Maxwell.

title: Joe Strummer 001
label: Ignition
description: This 32-track collection combines remastered rarities and unreleased oddities. More than a collectors’ compendium, though, it offers a welcome collage of a restless, empathic spirit.

title: Skylight
label: self-released
description: Completed in 2017 and shelved for almost a year, Pinegrove’s third record is smaller, softer, and closer to the chest.

title: Awful Swim
label: Adult Swim
description: Having relocated to L.A., the Atlanta rapper rapper brings his deadpan flow and subversive sense of humor to some of the strongest production he’s had yet, yielding a refreshingly mischievous album.

title: Drogas Wave
label: 1st and 15th
description: On his seventh album, the conscious hip-hop fallback poses a revisionist fantasy about underwater slaves sinking other slave ships—a premise he quickly abandons during these 24 tracks.

title: Konoyo
label: Kranky
description: On the least dense and most inquisitive album of his career, the experimental musician creates a fascinating dialogue between his technology and some of the world’s most ancient instruments.

title: DJ-Kicks
label: !K7
description: After the post-punk atmospheres of last year’s Love What Survives, Mount Kimbie return to dance music with a DJ set that proves them to be both adventurous selectors and cagey mixers.

title: Behold a Dark Horse
label: Marci Enterprises
description: The New York rapper’s skill and authority are so strong on his latest project it’s like listening to a director’s commentary without ever seeing the movie. It is also marred by his retrograde homophobia.

title: Resistance
label: Brainfeeder
description: A frequent collaborator of Babyface, Flying Lotus, and Kamasi Washington, the Los Angeles keyboardist brings a wide range of inspirations to bear on a fun, frothy record that’s slathered with vocoder.

title: Thunder Follows the Light
label: Transgressive
description: Jordan Lee’s latest record aims to make his beatific melodies and rich orchestrations match the gravity of his subject matter.

title: MITH
label: ‎Jagjaguwar‎
description: For his Jagjaguwar debut, the acclaimed 68-year-old sculptor offers a harrowing portrait of the United States and its systems for suffering. Then, he dances.

title: Art of Doubt
label: MMI / Crystal Math Music
description: Emily Haines leads her band into their seventh album with their own sound, immune to trends and the zeitgeist, full of big, broad rock anthems.

title: Elsewhere
label: Secret Songs
description: The Canadian DJ’s most polished solo release yet is an album of catchy, globe-trotting pop that showcases his talents as a songwriter, producer and curator.

title: iridescence
label: Question Everything
description: The group’s fourth record is a pummeling collection of mosh-pit conductors, crowded songs, and fleeting moments of delicacy.

label: Atlantic
description: Danielle Bregoli’s leap from meme to rapper continues with her debut mixtape that leans heavily on mimicry and trails dreadfully behind the current sound of hip-hop.

title: Quiet River of Dust Vol. 1
label: Anti-
description: On his first song-oriented album, the Arcade Fire’s composer-in-residence folds folk music and dissonance into delightful odes to nature’s pleasure and power.

title: The Hex
label: Secretly Canadian
description: On the final and best album from the acclaimed producer and overlooked singer/songwriter, a new intensity and urgency line even the most upbeat songs.

title: Piano & a Microphone 1983
label: Warner Bros.
description: This blessed collection of unreleased demos, recorded by Prince to cassette in a single take, is enthralling. It plays like both omen and artifact of his hit-making power.

title: Love in Shadow
label: Thrill Jockey
description: After sessions last year with Japanese improv legend Keiji Haino, the powerful metal trio ripped its newest songs open, filling the negative space with improvisational gusto to become a stunning band.

label: Motown
description: The Parisian rapper, born to Senegalese and Guinean immigrants, is determined to do with music what Kylian Mbappé did with soccer: change the national perception of who and what a Frenchman can be.

title: YBN: The Mixtape
label: self-released
description: Primarily showcasing its three core members, the YBN Collective’s first full-length captures the rough-around-the-edges charm of a group still figuring out exactly who and what it wants to be.

title: The Three EPs
label: Because Music
description: Keen pop instincts, a good sense of space, and a penchant for self-sabotage: That’s the Beta Band, epitomized by this 20th-anniversary reissue of their earliest works.

title: LP5000
label: Tiny Engines
description: In the face of label woes, a gentrifying hometown, and Donald Trump, Philadelphia’s other Springsteen acolytes thrive inside the tension between hug-and-chug uplift and political fatigue.

title: Return 0
label: REALMS
description: The London IDM polymath’s fourth album puts artificial intelligence in the composer’s seat, rounding out computer-generated rhythms and melodies with AI-penned lyrics sung by Koosha himself.

title: Infinite Moment
label: Kompakt
description: The Swedish producer takes the long view on his fifth album full of drifting compositions that knit together twin feelings of melancholy and hope.

title: 3 Feet High and Rising
label: Tommy Boy
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the groundbreaking 1989 debut album from hip-hop legends De La Soul.

title: Snow Bound
label: Fire
description: An architect of New Zealand’s fabled Dunedin sound returns with another dose of heavenly pop. This time, he may even be happy.

title: Million Dollars to Kill Me
label: Epitaph
description: With the help of Converge guitarist and veteran metal producer Kurt Ballou, the versatile emo band continues to mature with hints of Big Star and subgenre subversion.

title: 13 Rivers
label: New West
description: After fifty years and nearly twenty solo albums, the low-key guitar god finds new ways to renew old sentiments as a singer, songwriter, and instrumentalist on what may be his best album this century.

title: Magic Ship
label: Nonesuch
description: After the ascent of her electronic-pop duo Sylvan Esso, Amelia Meath reassembled her old vocal folk trio for a surprise second album—a charming reflection on age, friendship, and play.

title: East Atlanta Love Letter
label: LVRN
description: With his chilly vocals, minimalist beats, and conditions of the heart, the Atlanta singer finds a groove but has little to say about human relations outside of his own self-important quagmire.

title: Return of the Trill
label: II Trill Enterprises
description: On his first solo album that exists not because he’s in the habit of making records but because he has something to say, the UGK cofounder finally sounds confident by himself.

title: Apologia
label: Príncipe Discos
description: During the three years since their last release, the Portuguese trio have built a soundworld of peculiar synths, drum machines, and samples, all in pursuit of hard-to-define moods.

title: Chris
label: Because Music
description: The kinetic French singer Hélöise Letissier lets us into the whole of her life, creating an electric blend of unforgettable imagery, emotional depth, and lurid pop-funk.

title: Ithra
label: Aerophonic
description: Three players with deep roots in Chicago’s contemporary jazz scene come together in an unusually empathetic exchange of ideas, where the gap between listening and reacting is practically nonexistent.

title: frozenthere
label: Samedi
description: The New York quartet’s scant and downtempo album deftly uses stillness as a way to pull listeners deeper into the music.

title: For Ever
label: XL
description: On their second album, the buzzy UK group only sometimes overcomes their style-over-substance sound that coats their glossy songs.

title: Emanon
label: Blue Note
description: With his ever-ambitious quartet, the legendary saxophonist from many of Miles Davis’ best records again reimagines his own standards, now with the help of a graphic novel and an orchestra.

title: Lilac Everything
label: Liberation
description: Using pitched-down vocals, the Australian singer-songwriter finds new folds and textures in traditional pop songwriting with the help of producer Tobias Jesso Jr.

title: Room 25
label: self-released
description: The Chicago rapper’s second album is a transcendent coming-of-age tale built around cosmic jazz and neo-soul, delivered by a woman deeply invested in her interiority and that of the world around her.

title: Heat
label: DDS
description: An unannounced album from the Japanese producer sounds as mysterious as ever, but his once chilly techno has warmed and deepened, and a communal, even celebratory spirit has come to the fore.

title: Hex of Infinite Binding EP
label: Merge
description: John Darnielle confronts death once more, this time through a series of mortals, spirits, and superheroes.

title: We’re Not Talking
label: Wichita
description: The Brisbane guitar-pop trio infuses conversational vocals with deep emotional resonance on a sophomore album that spotlights the refreshing contributions of drummer Riley Jones.

title: In Another Life
label: Constellation
description: On his first album in almost seven years, the Toronto artist uses ambient pop to craft a masterful, dreamlike world where songs luxuriate for 24 minutes and Dan Bejar shows up to sing about Paris.

title: Mandy (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Lakeshore
description: In his final completed film score, the late composer and experimental musician revels in extreme sounds, delving into black metal, menacing ambient, doom drone, and piercing orchestrations.

title: Battle Lines
label: Domino
description: The New York duo’s second album is tasteful to a fault, joining gentle electronics with polite indie rock and vaguely wistful lyrics. Despite the title, it’s a record that avoids discord at all cost.

title: Monsters Exist
label: ACP
description: The brothers’ ninth studio album marks their second comeback; there are glimmers of their crowd-pleasing, mind-expanding rave heyday, but too often the material lacks a sense of purpose.

title: Collapse EP
label: Warp
description: The renaissance of Richard D. James continues with his latest EP, a knotty, meticulous, and joyous collection that ranks among his best late-career albums.

title: Pastoral
label: Anti-Ghost Moon Ray
description: The Brighton electronic musician’s third LP belongs to a proud tradition of English satire, plumbing the depths of the nation’s psyche and twisting it to wryly discomforting ends.

title: Mother of My Children
label: Saddle Creek
description: Written as her loved ones protested at Standing Rock, during the dissolution of a queer romance, and after the death of a beloved mentor, Katherine Paul’s debut is a work of intersectional mourning.

title: Rid of Me
label: Island
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit PJ Harvey’s searing and monumental album from 1993.

title: I’m a Dream
label: Saraba AB
description: On her second album, the Gambian-Swedish musician sings movingly about grief and otherness, but her rich voice too often gets lost in busy, formulaic pop production.

title: Twisted Crystal
label: DFA
description: The New York quintet diverges from its dance-punk roots, stirring in dashes of surf-pop, big beat, and classic rock on an album that explores the mysteries of the universe and the human psyche.

title: Gave in Rest
label: Ba Da Bing Records
description: The Canadian composer’s latest album marks a subtle but significant shift in her music-making, marking her most extensive foray to date into the hands-on, real-time realm of studio recording.

title: N°2/Âme Debout/Paix
label: Anthology Recordings
description: Beauty and chaos intermingle in these early-1970s touchstones of avant-garde folk. The French-Portuguese singer’s unearthly voice and searching lyrics made them cult classics.

title: Heavy Music: The Complete Cameo Recordings 1966-1967
label: ABKCO
description: This overdue anthology of Seger’s earliest recordings preserves a handful of singles by a young Detroit garage-rock band that blended rock’n’roll and R&B, party music and passion.

title: Heaven
label: Partisan
description: Written amid a period of intra-band tumult, Dilly Dally’s thrilling second album foregrounds frontwoman Kate Monks’ singular voice as she riffs on themes of power, sex, confidence, and self-care.

title: Moon 2
label: Western Vinyl
description: The Brooklyn band’s latest is one of their best, a shifting and teasing kind of electro-funk that exists on their own plane of gravity.

title: Double Negative
label: Sub Pop
description: The austere trio has profoundly warped their slowcore sound to create an ambitious, modern wonder of an album, an exploration of the song as an imperfect conduit of feeling.

title: Voodoo Magic
label: Axis
description: A set of one-take recordings from Jeff Mills’ four-piece techno-jazz-funk fusion band—and one terrific Terrence Parker remix—are a reminder of the importance of editing.

title: RUNT EP
label: Method
description: This five-track EP is a dazzling sampler for one of grime’s most promising young talents and a dismaying survey from inside the life of a small-time drug peddler in a British suburb.

title: My New Moon
label: Dualtone
description: On his seventh studio album, the Philadelphia singer-songwriter reckons with losses both personal and political in search of a new beginning.

title: SPACEMAN
label: Black Butter
description: The latest project from the rising UK rapper is unsettling but addictive, enormous in scope, and plays front to back like the ultimate hybrid mixtape.

title: Mothe EP
label: Human Re Sources
description: The rapper, singer, and designer envisions transition as the ultimate creative moment on a release that transforms her racing thoughts into crackling electricity.

title: Guess What? EP
label: So Way Out
description: The 17-minute EP is a fun but somewhat predictable placeholder until the West Coast gunslinger’s next proper project.

title: Tomorrow
label: Haight Brand
description: The Chicago soul outfit’s latest album is well-arranged and reflective, content with being pretty and sitting still.

title: Dancehall
label: Animal 63
description: On their debut album, Guillaume and Jonathan Alric make big, staid dance music tailored for main stages at music festivals where subtlety falls victim to the pursuit of big moments.

title: Another Life
label: Pan
description: The Berlin duo’s debut album balances club music’s repetitive cadences with all-out chaos—an end-of-the-world soundtrack shot through with fierce, defiant rage.

title: Lady Lady
label: EQT
description: All cognac and white linen, the Virginia R&B musician’s debut album is steeped in quiet storm and beefed up with crisp drums and booming production: a sophisticated, seductive mix.

title: Egypt Station
label: Capitol
description: Part of the Beatle’s charm lies in his vacillation between the banal and the profound, sometimes within a single song. Despite its dark moments, his 17th solo album is firmly within this tradition.

title: And Nothing Hurt
label: Fat Possum
description: On what may or may not be the final album from his legendary space-rock project, Jason Pierce finally sounds as though he has a hold on his passions, preoccupations, and demons.

title: Head Cage
label: Relapse
description: The Mid-Atlantic’s grindcore standard bearers have never done it better than they do on their sixth studio album, the strangest, strongest, and most accessible record in the band’s 20-year history.

title: Love, Loss, and Auto-Tune
label: Joyful Noise
description: R&B’s weirdest—and most radical—weirdo modernizes his sound on an album that uses Auto-Tune to convey the ecstasies of love, the misery of loss, and the economic desperation of life in Trumpland.

title: Shelley’s on Zenn-La
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Radiohead’s favorite cellist steps out of their shadow on an album composed largely of beat-oriented electronic music influenced by—but not excessively reverent toward—the work of Aphex Twin.

title: QUARTERTHING
label: self-released
description: Following 2016’s iiiDrops, the Chicago rapper returns with another album that defies expectations. There is a greater range of flows explored, a greater range of tones discovered, and a sharper focus throughout.

title: Trap Muzik
label: Atlantic
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a pivotal album in the history of Atlanta and rap itself.

title: Ecce Homo
label: Touch
description: The Turkish sound artist balances technical precision, emotional potency, and trenchant cultural critique on an album whose individual sounds are as compelling as their widescreen narratives.

title: The Song Remains the Same
label: Atlantic
description: A deluxe reissue of the band’s 1976 live fantasia highlights its charms and absurdities. It remains a messy, psychedelic document of Zeppelin in their imperial era.

title: Selected Early Keyboard Works
label: Blank Forms
description: A new collection of the Swedish composer’s early experiments on Fender Rhodes, synthesizers, and magnetic tape shines a long overdue spotlight on an unsung electronic pioneer.

title: Magus
label: Sacred Bones
description: The Baton Rouge sludge-metal quartet’s fifth proper full-length marks the latest tsunami in the endless storm of defeaning sound, political fury, and overwhelming prolificness that is Thou.

title: Hope River
label: Diamond Studios
description: Following his high-profile features on records by Kanye and Kendrick Lamar, the veteran dancehall deejay returns with an idiosyncratic album that subtly challenges the conventions of dancehall itself.

title: Bawskee
label: Alamo
description: The rapper’s joyless debut is the sound of a scam artist. It is unoriginal, outdated, and one of the most stylistically unappealing projects to come from the SoundCloud scene.

title: Great Thunder EP
label: Merge
description: Katie Crutchfield revisits six tracks originally recorded in 2012, waving away the lo-fi haze that blanketed much of her early work to reveal her celebrated skills as a storyteller and singer.

title: Safe in the Hands of Love
label: Warp
description: Yves Tumor’s latest album is a benchmark in experimental music. It is searing and borderless, music that is aware of oppressive confinement, and music with an intoxicating urge to be free.

title: Reign Supreme
label: self-released
description: Danny Brown’s ear for talent outweighs his larger-than-life persona on a mixtape that finds him ceding center stage to accentuate and support the voices of other rappers in his crew.

title: Live at Funkhaus Berlin, 10th May 2018
label: self-released
description: On what is only his second official live album in his 20-year career, the celebrated electronic producer demonstrates his range—and his mastery of tension and release.

title: Zion
label: Northern Spy
description: Gabriel Birnbaum’s urban Americana project intersperses grit and gloom with alluring glimpses of deliverance in the first installment of a planned musical novel on young adult life in Brooklyn.

title: Kamikaze
label: Aftermath
description: All across his 10th album, the more things change, the more Eminem stays the same.

title: Joy as an Act of Resistance
label: Partisan
description: The riffs come hard, fuzzy, and fast on the Bristol punks’ deeply passionate second album—and the platitudes follow close behind.

title: KIN: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack
label: Temporary Residence
description: The Scottish group’s action flick soundtrack lacks their usual maximalist peaks but offers impressionistic sketches.

title: Paraffin
label: Backwoodz Studioz
description: The latest release from stalwart New York underground rap duo Armand Hammer, aka billy woods and Elucid, continues their hot streak. Even as they take on weighty societal issues, the pair maintain a light touch and a near-telepathic bond.

title: New Hymn to Freedom
label: The Leaf Label
description: Luke Abbott’s synth/sax/drums trio illustrates the links between London’s fertile jazz scene and longstanding psychedelic traditions in six vibrant, unedited improvisations.

title: Magick Songs
label: Dine Alone
description: Three years into their return from the majors, the Orrall brothers have finally blossomed into a proper rock band—on an album that deconstructs the idea of what a proper rock band should sound like.

title: Big Red Machine
label: PEOPLE
description: The debut collaboration of Justin Vernon and Aaron Dessner is gorgeous and ponderous, a document of a creative process that feels a bit like watching someone get purposefully lost.

title: I’ve Tortured You Long Enough
label: Sub Pop
description: Noel Heroux of Hooray for Earth enlists his wife, Jessica Zambri, for a bombastic, exhausting album that betrays a deep desire to emulate Funeral-era Arcade Fire.

title: Hunter
label: Domino
description: On her first album in five years, the goth-rock guitar virtuoso abandons her typically detached perspective to ruminate on gender, sexuality, and identity with newfound urgency.

title: Clube Da Esquina
label: Odeon
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit one of the most ambitious albums in Brazilian history.

title: Music From Big Pink
label: Capitol
description: Beyond its myth or this questionable new remix, the debut album from the Band made roots music sound as impressionistic and idiosyncratic as any other kind of rock’n’roll. It was revolutionary.

title: Slide
label: 100% Electronica
description: The “vaporwave opera” tag is a red herring: The electronic musician formerly known as Mirror Kisses has grown into his most fully realized vision of pop yet.

title: Studio Barnhus Volym 1
label: Studio Barnhus
description: The immersive and warm-hearted comp from the Swedish label is filled with pop oddities and floor-filling house tracks from both big names and newcomers.

title: Rainier Fog
label: BMG
description: The grunge stalwarts’ sixth album revisits their Seattle roots, with a sound harkening back to the early ’90s, when they were swept up in a wave of Pacific Northwest acts achieving international fame.

title: Little World
label: POW Recordings
description: The latest album from the Dallas trio is a trove of middle-class rap flexes. It sounds like a dark realm all to itself, the full-on encapsulation of their long-running operation.

title: I’m Terry
label: Upset the Rhythm
description: The Australian quartet both epitomizes and transcends the indie-pop aesthetic on an album that balances lighthearted wordplay with serious political commentary.

title: Weed Garden EP
label: Sub Pop
description: Although it’s neither as purposeful nor as prescient as many of his earlier EPs, Sam Beam’s latest release carries far more weight than its self-deprecating title implies.

title: Bloom
label: Capitol
description: The Australian singer’s second album exudes a chic kind of vulnerability. It is a warm and delicate pop album about life as a young gay man.

title: Performance
label: City Slang
description: On their shaggy, wild-eyed seventh album, the Austin rockers sound like a band rejuvenated—or, at least, a band that remembers what people liked about its music in the first place.

title: Hello, Summer
label: Stereo Vision
description: The New Jersey jazzman combines hip-hop sensibilities with the precision of Count Basie in a collection of highly controlled compositions that are nonetheless warm, languid, and dedicated to the funk.

title: Only Self
label: Southern Lord
description: The full-length debut from the Philadelphia metalcore band folds in industrial and ambient textures into a brutal sound that’s still, thankfully, based around big, slamming breakdowns.

title: Indigo
label: Captured Tracks
description: Jack Tatum’s Los Angeles album finds him expanding his ambitions, but neither his songwriting nor his mood-setting measure up to the polish or the scale of his aspirational, accessible indie pop.

title: ensley
label: self-released
description: The latest project from L.A.-based rapper is a fascinating, seemingly unfinished collage of spoken interludes, gorgeous beats, and low-fi snippets that reckons with a life of gold and faith.

title: Dance on the Blacktop
label: Relapse
description: On their third album, the Philadelphia shoegaze band’s tried-and-true arrangements are not terribly original, but they are deeply felt.

title: Thanks for Everything
label: Mega Collider
description: Stephan Jenkins puts a modern-rock spin on Bon Iver, Chastity Belt, “Song to the Siren,” and more on this intentionally earnest but unintentionally tragic covers album.

title: The Long Walk
label: Sacred Bones
description: The Brooklyn industrial act trades its signature drum machine for Guardian Alien/Liturgy drummer Greg Fox, harnessing his intensity to fuel their most unified—and most deranged—record to date.

title: Dream Songs
label: You Are Accepted
description: The Majical Cloudz alum trades electronic pop for guitar, piano, and strings on an unflinchingly candid debut solo album that sets his singular voice free to preen, wander, and soar.

title: The Big Chang Theory
label: KILFMB
description: The Bay Area rapper continues to make waves with an album of pop ‘n’ snap party records bookended by two more heartfelt cuts.

title: Lightbourn
label: Cosmic Range
description: Toronto’s foremost experimental soundscaper also turns out to be a surprisingly tender country-soul crooner on an album divided between psych-soul workouts and solitary acoustic ruminations.

title: Poaa
label: Nyege Nyege Tapes
description: On this highlight from the Nyege Nyege Tapes label, Bamba Pana takes a more abrasive approach to Tanzanian singeli music: drilling synths and tinny drum machines played at impossibly fast speeds.

title: Skinless X-1
label: Hausu Mountain
description: On her first official LP as Fire-Toolz, Chicago producer Angel Marcloid uses vaporwave’s expansive palette to explore the identities that the internet enables users to absorb, process, and redistribute.

title: Total 18
label: Kompakt
description: The label that defined Cologne techno may have uncoupled from dance music’s zeitgeist, but on its 18th annual compilation, Kompakt finds freedom in its ability to keep on Kompakting on.

title: Marauder
label: Matador
description: On their sixth record, the New York band is stuck in a Medium Mood and a new producer doesn’t help energize their increasingly frozen-in-time sound.

title: Parts
label: Joyful Noise
description: Sima Cunningham and Macie Stewart have worked with Chance the Rapper, Vic Mensa, and Wilco. On their first album as a duo, they make improvisational art rock with an inquisitive, surrealist bent.

title: Burritos, Inspiration Point, Fork Balloon Sports, Cards in the Spokes, Automatic Biographies, Kites, Kung Fu, Trophies, Banana Peels We’ve Slipped on, and Egg Shells We’ve Tippy Toed Over
label: Man With Gun
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit a touchstone of Midwestern emo, the 1995 debut from Cap’n Jazz.

title: Cheap Storage
label: Atlantic Rhythms
description: The Los Angeles techno producer’s second album is sharp and focused. Maymind does a lot with very little to make gratifying soundscapes that are easy to sink into.

title: Punishment in Flesh
label: Profound Lore
description: Abetted by a handful of fellow musicians from the hardcore scene, Boston’s Justin DeTore makes thick, impenetrable death metal that’s desolate and filled with tension.

title: Go to School
label: 4AD
description: Recorded in their parents’ basement, the second album by Long Island brothers Michael and Brian D’Addario is a musical about a monkey that features Todd Rundgren as the primate’s father.

title: Anno
label: Moshi Moshi
description: We hear the avant-garde composer’s antic voice here and there on her interpretation of Vivaldi’s masterpiece. If it’s not a mind meld, it’s at least as fun as a Face Swap filter on Instagram.

title: Where There’s Smoke
label: Palms Out Sounds
description: A rapper, singer, producer, visual artist, and activist, the Philly native puts all of his diverse talents to work on a debut album that is equal parts political manifesto and bold artistic statement.

title: Negro Swan
label: Domino
description: Dev Hynes’ fourth album as Blood Orange focuses on black depression, sketching his anxious alt-pop, progressive R&B, indie hip-hop, downtempo rock, and spacey chillwave into a minimalist emulsion.

title: Ekuka
label: Nyege Nyege Tapes
description: In a departure from its typically cutting-edge electronics, the Ugandan label Nyege Nyege Tapes unearths vintage recordings of an mbira master whose lo-fi sonics are every bit as arresting.

title: Orpheus vs. the Sirens
label: Obol for Charon
description: In a twist, the Brownsville rapper projects the streetwise narratives of his youth through the lens of Greek mythology—an audacious move, but his hypnotic voice and evocative writing pull it off.

title: Träden
label: Subliminal Sounds
description: The Swedish counterculture legends formerly known as Träd, Gräs och Stenar revisit the universe they created in the 1970s, building woolly, choogling rock songs that sound both earthy and sublime.

title: Book of Travelers
label: Nonesuch
description: After the 2016 election, the Brooklyn musician embarked on a cross-country train trip that yielded an album that inextricably links America’s abstract political reality with the human lives it has shaped.

title: Smote Reverser
label: Castle Face
description: On their new record, the California group remain deliriously unhinged but indulge in prog-metal fantasies.

title: Portrait With Firewood
label: R&S
description: Taking inspiration from the performance artist Marina Abramović, the UK bass musician’s second album uses chamber instruments and spoken-word fragments to get at the messy business of human intimacy.

title: Desire Loop
label: Mysteries of the Deep
description: The New York-based electronic musician has done everything from shoegaze to pop to film scores, but her first solo album in 14 years is distinguished less by her range than by her ability to focus.

title: detritus preterit selections
label: UNO NYC
description: Producer William Harrison King puts quantity before quality on this free, 30-track compilation of sketches, demos, and experiments whose most exciting moments highlight his flair for minimalist composition.

title: Slime Language
label: Young Stoner Life
description: Thug offers up a nice summertime party record, his most cheerful, undemanding project since his early mixtapes.

title: Cheyenne
label: Counter
description: The ambient, intimate debut from singer Conner Youngblood uses layered folk impressionism to evoke the kinds of feelings that elude easy definition.

title: Sweetener
label: Republic
description: After years of searching, Ariana Grande has found her true voice. Sweetener is an exemplary pop album, radiating with low-key joy and newfound love.

title: Clear Tamei EP / Steel Mogu EP
label: Gloo
description: On a brightly colored pair of EPs, the UK musician builds upon the fantasy world he introduced on 2017’s Neō Wax Bloom: a cartoon universe characterized by digital overload.

title: ONEPOINTFIVE
label: Republic
description: On the Portland rapper’s surprise “EP/LP/Mixtape/Album,” his feel-good music starts to lose some of the stained, lived-in quality that once made it so rich.

title: Voluptuous Worship of Rapture and Response
label: Prosthetic
description: Australia’s Bob Nekrasov fuses black metal’s gravelly aesthetic with heavy riffs and gloriously over-the-top imagery; it’s a celebration of the very contradictions that make metal so thrilling.

title: Old Rockhounds Never Die
label: Memphis Industries
description: On her second album, the kaleidoscopic future-folk sounds of Odetta Hartman are brought into immaculate focus.

title: Our Garden Needs Its Flowers
label: Awesome Tapes From Africa
