description: A 1985 album from two Ivory Coast musicians explores the sounds of 1970s country and folk; it amounts to a joyful vision of a world without borders.

title: Thank You For Today
label: Atlantic
description: The ninth album from Ben Gibbard and Co. is their strongest album of the 2010s, a dubious achievement that nonetheless deserves recognition for its rare moments of shining, indie-pop songwriting.

title: The Fat Of the Land
label: XL
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the Prodigy’s testosterone-fuelled U.S. invasion.

title: Pure EP
label: self-released
description: On her first EP under her own name, the artist formerly known as Wynter Gordon returns to R&B; it’s a record marked by her striking voice and emotional candor.

title: Mulberry Violence
label: Baby Halo
description: With Youth Lagoon in the rear-view, Trevor Powers remains a sure-handed sculptor of sound. His voice here surges to the fore, newly exposed and digitally treated.

title: Future Me Hates Me
label: Carpark
description: The debut from Auckland indie rockers is just really impressive—hook-filled songs filled with energy and attitude, written with depth and played masterfully.

title: Slimeball 3
label: Paradise East
description: At his best—as on this third installment of his Slimeball series—Nudy can distill the influence of Atlanta’s integral artists into his a world of his own.

title: At Weddings
label: Saddle Creek
description: Sarah Beth Tomberlin’s debut album traces the hole left by the loss of her faith, filling it in with wave-like acoustic phrases and a sharp-eyed attention to everyday details.

title: The Diet
label: Sub Pop
description: The former Smith Westerns member’s second album represents a return to his core strengths: crystalline, cosmically ornate melodies and wryly clear-eyed lyrics.

title: Suffuse
label: Ba Da Bing Records
description: After tentative vocal experiments on 2016’s R M H Q, the New Zealand guitarist crafts an entire album around guest singers, all women, in which he progressively blurs the traces of his own handiwork.

title: Be the Cowboy
label: Dead Oceans
description: The fifth album from the singular songwriter is her greatest to date. From the music to her emotions, Mitski has the power to make the complex seem dazzlingly clear.

title: Tangerine Reef
label: Domino
description: Composed by Avey Tare, Geologist, and Deakin, AnCo’s second audiovisual album reckons abstractly with the environmental devastation and the potentially horrifying consequences yet to come.

title: Time
label: Brainfeeder
description: Drummer Louis Cole’s sidelong blend of hard funk and soft pop—aided by guest spots from Thundercat and Brad Mehldau—remains delightfully sly and off-kilter.

title: Flintlock
label: Treasure Chest Entertainment
description: Given a leg up by Roc Marciano, the veteran rapper returns with his own take on classic, streetwise East Coast rap: tales of nefarious business delivered in painstaking, and often chilling, detail.

title: forever & ever
label: SALES Universe
description: On their second record, the Orlando duo create a world of cozy, minimalist pop.

title: Heart Head West
label: Downtown
description: The actress’ full-length debut is firm in its influences but lacking in variety.

title: Life’s a Trip
label: 10K Projects
description: Chasing hits and fighting against his own strengths prevent Trippie Redd’s debut album from having a seismic impact.

title: Nostrum Grocers
label: Ruby Yacht
description: Having evolved from his early days as art rap’s cocky philosopher in chief, milo displays a newfound confidence alongside Elucid, a grittier and more seasoned lyricist.

title: The Voice of Love
label: Sacred Bones
description: The reissue of Julee Cruise’s second album, featuring David Lynch and Angelo Badalamenti, follows the singer on her dizzying dream-pop trajectory, where love and loss are flip sides of the same coin.

title: Being Woke Ain’t Fun
label: New Deal Collectives
description: The Chicago rapper is something of an outcast in his hometown’s hip-hop scene, delivering slick punchlines over boom-bap beats. His third project in four months is his best, but he’s got room to grow.

title: Bell House
label: Polyvinyl
description: Bubblegum surf-pop meets Midwestern earnestness on the Kansas City quintet’s sweet, funny, but sometimes inscrutable sophomore album.

title: Queen
label: Young Money Entertainment
description: On her most rap-oriented release yet, Nicki jettisons all the industry madness, drowns out the noise, and creates rap the way she believes it should sound.

title: RAM 7: August 1791
label: Willibelle Publishing & Sales
description: With history and folklore as its backdrop, the Haitian band moves further away from Western styles to focus on Creole tradition and West African roots.

title: Locations, Processed
label: Moog Records
description: The veteran field-recording artist turns his microphones on New York City in the attempt to capture something essential lurking within the ephemeral.

title: Body
label: Northern Spy
description: The Necks’ 20th album is as laser-focused on repetition as ever. But for the first time, the trio indulges its rock’n’roll instincts, resulting in one of the most powerful albums in the band’s catalog.

title: Nearer My God
label: Triple Crown
description: The St. Louis band’s third album is big, beautiful, and audacious, an artful leap toward creating the new sound of rafter-shaking indie rock.

title: Loyalty Over Love
label: Sick Wid It
description: The latest project from the Sacramento by way of Mobile rapper is a rich portrait of loneliness, suspicion, and weariness, showcasing his eye for observation and a knack for self-examination.

title: Earl
label: OFWGKTA
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit Earl Sweatshirt’s debut mixtape, the keystone to Odd Future’s success.

title: Born Again in the Voltage
label: Important Records
description: After the complex programming of last year’s Patterns of Consciousness, the Berlin-based composer explores new realms with her modular synthesizer, incorporating cello, voice, and doom-laden drones.

title: Bandwagonesque / Thirteen / Grand Prix / Songs from Northern Britain / Howdy!
label: Sony Legacy
description: These vinyl reissues of the Scottish power-pop luminaries’ outstanding Creation Records output showcase a band whose music captures the feeling of living with the music you love.

title: What Another Man Spills
label: Merge
description: On this sparkling reissue of an early career highlight, the act that billed itself as “the most fucked-up country band in Nashville” revels in the ecstasy of influence.

title: Late 20s
label: YOU.KNOW.I.GOT.IT Entertainment
description: On the Berkeley rapper’s second album, he struggles with depression in stark, evocative terms, confirming his stature as one of the most intensely cathartic narrators out there.

title: Coup de Grace
label: Virgin
description: The louche UK singer returns with an album that thrusts ahead quickly and painlessly but leaves you itching to shower off its overpowering cologne the second it’s over.

title: Devotion
label: Domino
description: Produced by Mica Levi, Tirzah’s debut is a compelling vision of what imperfect pop music can be—joyful in both sound and feeling precisely because both seem so out-of-step and asymmetrical.

title: Jake Shears
label: Freida Jean Records
description: The Scissor Sisters frontman’s solo debut could’ve been a disaster: A pop star moseys down to New Orleans to find “real music.” But if you’re not a stickler for authenticity, it’s actually irresistible.

title: Dia del Asesinato
label: Soul Assassins
description: The veteran producer and Cypress Hill alum reconnects with his New York roots on a fun, if not terribly challenging, revivalist romp surrounded by outer-borough icons and a few hungry upstarts.

title: Lithium Zion
label: Sub Pop
description: The Melbourne quartet’s fifth album doesn’t counteract any Sonic Youth comparisons, but it does conjure an alternate history where the rock formalism of Goo and Dirty became the band’s defining sound.

title: Live at Third Man Records ||| Nashville & Cass Corridor
label: Third Man
description: Released through Third Man’s record club, Jack White’s 3xLP live set takes some of his knotty, obtuse songs from this year’s Boarding House Reach and lets them breathe on stage.

title: Dissolvi
label: Ghostly
description: No longer content to deconstruct the droning sounds of his former band, the Emeralds alum gives Kompakt-style minimal techno a try.

title: Emergency Raps, Vol. 3
label: Mutant Academy
description: The Virginia producer lays out chopped loops for the surrealistic rapper Koncept Jack$on, whose narrow-eyed presence plays off the rest of the Mutant Academy crew.

title: 4Milli
label: OVO Sound
description: Across 25 torturous minutes, the Toronto rapper doesn’t make a single lasting impression as a performer, storyteller, or craftsman. He’ll do well on OVO.

title: Vicious Circles EP
label: Planet Mu
description: In their latest joint release, Kanye producer Sinjin Hawke and Jlin collaborator Zora Jones combine human voices and digital processing to manifest a seamless fusion of flesh and code.

title: Survive the Summer EP
label: Island
description: On the embattled rapper’s latest EP, Iggy Azalea knows what a good rap song sounds like in the abstract but is simply incapable of making one.

title: Someday Everything Will Be Fine
label: Merge
description: The North Carolina trio’s fifth record show a softer side, but some moments yearn for their trademark snarkiness.

title: Genericana
label: Western Vinyl
description: Despite its title, Joseph O’Connell’s second release for Western Vinyl is his most distinctive release to date, an elegant study of life’s circularity set against a backdrop of slowcore folk and woozy rock.

title: Paradise: The Sound of Ivor Raymonde
label: Bella Union
description: The composer behind Dusty Springfield’s “I Only Want to Be With You” also worked with David Bowie, the Walker Brothers, and Ian Dury. A new compilation reveals how he helped shape 1960s British pop.

title: Astroworld
label: Epic
description: Travis Scott’s third album is inarguably his strongest to date. His skill as a curator helps sculpt a sticky, humid, psychedelic world with dazzling production and odd pleasures at every turn.

title: The Nature of Imitation
label: Brainfeeder
description: On his second solo album, Austrian producer and Flying Lotus associate Oliver Johnson puts his own eclectic spin on FlyLo’s brand of over-caffeinated astral jazz and hiccuping robo-breaks.

title: Stay Dangerous
label: Def Jam
description: Filled with numbing vulgarity, warmed-over nostalgia, and actual nursery rhymes, YG’s third studio album is a mindless step backward.

title: Baby Grand
label: Merge
description: After three albums packed with peach-sweet melodies, a move to the West Coast inspires one of indie rock’s most underrated songwriters to supercharge his sound and upgrade his showmanship.

title: Ba Suba, Ak Jamm EP
label: Grand Closing
description: The Brooklyn rapper has a reputation for emulating Earl Sweatshirt’s brutal atmospherics and determined flow, but what sets him apart is the emotional precision he brings to his debut EP.

title: Amici
label: Upset the Rhythm
description: The Melbourne post-punk band makes a messy life feel easier to untangle, writing songs with an appealing simplicity, buoyancy, and emotional openness.

title: Faith
label: Epic
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the liminal sex-pop of George Michael’s 1987 debut album.

title: There’s Always Glimmer
label: Orindal
description: The Chicago-based songwriter sees singing about personal experiences as an act of violence, but her debut LP translates that dark view into 34 minutes of surprisingly serene, perceptive storytelling.

title: At WAR With Myself Too
label: Grind Hard
description: A decade into the East Nashville rapper’s latest incarnation, he delves into the dark corners of his mind on an album that’s dense, prickly, and full of jarring personal details.

title: Manhunter Original Motion Picture Music
label: Waxwork
description: Michael Mann’s 1986 film was a critical and commercial flop, but its soundtrack has proved a major inspiration for the music supervision on projects like Drive and “Stranger Things.”

title: Channel Tres EP
label: Godmode
description: Channel Tres barely avoided the EDM world. And thank god for that. He turns in a debut EP of dark and deep hip-house with tons of promise.

title: Qualm
label: Ninja Tune
description: The Hamburg musician’s second album is a spartan mix of techno, acid, EBM, and coldwave. Even at her most damaged, Helena Hauff’s take on noise is nothing short of opulent.

title: Swimming
label: Warner Bros.
description: On his wounded fifth album, Mac Miller sings deftly about heartbreak and his mental state, capturing his resignation without turning sadness into a performative spectacle.

title: At Your Leisure
label: Topshelf
description: The Chicago-based band sounds more consistent—but also more risk-averse—than ever on a guitar-driven album that’s as peaceful and unchallenging as its title suggests.

title: Sleep Like It’s Winter
label: Newhere
description: Jim O’Rourke doesn’t much care for ambient music, so it makes sense that his first ambient album picks apart the genre and scrutinizes its attempts to produce truly structureless music.

title: Oli Gumm
label: трип
description: The five tracks here are among the most satisfying productions the Icelandic musician has released, a mix of comic, deranged, and weirdly sensual moods.

title: Repeat/Metal/Made Available/Live 80-81
label: Light in the Attic
description: A set of reissues of the British experimental trio’s non-album work, including a Peel sessions EP, live LP, and posthumous anthology, reveals the group’s restless, radical openness.

title: Book of Life
label: Erased Tapes
description: On his first solo album since his 2016 collaboration with Jan Jelinek, the experimental vibraphonist blurs the edges of his instrument in compositions both abstract and warmly sentimental.

title: Nova
label: Wedidit
description: Henry Steinway’s second full-length largely abandons the cool-kid stylistic tics of his debut for something bigger, brighter, and wholly anonymous.

title: Bringing the Backline
label: self-released
description: If Bristol-based songwriter Ellis Jones’ witty yet melancholy final album as Trust Fund has an overarching theme, it’s how deeply disenchanted he feels with making music.

title: Swervo
label: Machine Entertainment Group
description: The Chicago rapper’s latest project as his alter-ego named Swervo is all velocity. He delivers some of his starkest verses like a steamroller, almost completely desensitized.

title: Head in the Clouds
label: 88rising
description: For this 88rising showcase, Joji, Rich Brian, AUGUST 08, and the rest of the label all act like promising pop stars but are often overshadowed by the outside talent they bring along.

title: Change the Station / Mind Made Up
label: Mute
description: Two reissues from the Manchester veterans track the progress of their post-punk/disco fusions into the 1990s and 2000s—an uneven path, but their freewheeling energy still charms.

title: Teatime Dub Encounters EP
label: Caroline International
description: On their collaborative EP, the UK electronic duo provides a lush and polished bed of sound for Iggy Pop to grouse about the state of the world.

title: Fine
label: Dais
description: On his third and final album as SONOIO, Alessandro Cortini of Nine Inch Nails combines the brooding intensity of Trent Reznor’s band with arena-rock melodies in the vein of U2 and Depeche Mode.

title: Ares
label: Pina
description: The reggaeton stalwart and Latin trap pioneer embraces contemporary pop and hip-hop sounds on an uneven album that is at its most interesting when it verges into soul, salsa, and other novel styles.

title: Amazon to LeFrak EP
label: Phantom Limb
description: The debut EP from Cibo Matto veteran Miho Hatori builds on her former band’s experimental pop aesthetic while dialing down their quirky tendencies and moving into more mature subject matter.

title: Bag of Holding
label: NNA Tapes
description: Singer-songwriter Paco Cathcart taps into mysticism on his newest release as the Cradle, something fantastical, folky, and intensely imaginative.

title: A Heart From Your Shadow
label: Mondoj
description: Mixed by Jim O’Rourke, the duo’s debut is a progression of left turns and interruptions—drone blasts, electronic spasms, lyrical cello—whose unpredictability mimics the rhythms of city life.

title: Silk Canvas
label: self-released
description: The debut album from the Nigerian-American sisters in VanJess is a captivating fusion of 1990s R&B with contemporary electronic touches; its defining feature is the sisters’ uncanny synchronicity.

title: I Don’t Want: The Gold Fire Sessions
label: Downtown
description: The singer’s latest mixtape is soulful, summery, and without borders. Thanks in part to the production of Mixpak’s Dre Skull, Santigold commits to a careful interpolation of the dancehall sound.

title: Poison
label: MCA
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit a 1990 R&B blockbuster that bridged the gap between new jack swing and hip-hop soul.

title: Daniel Aged
label: Quality Time
description: One half of the brother act Inc. makes his solo debut with a satisfying collection of ambient-funk instrumentals that sound easy without being facile and chill without ever becoming soporific.

title: Kill the Lights
label: Slumberland
description: The master of the micro-song goes power pop on an ambitious release whose songs slide along the spectrum from sadness to madness, capturing Molina’s grief over a lost love.

title: Family Portrait
label: Brainfeeder
description: On his debut album, the UK producer attempts to shake the shackles of “lo-fi house” in search of a more nuanced understanding of dance-music nostalgia, but he can’t quite escape the shadow of his influences.

title: Opal
label: Requiem Pour Un Twister
description: Lionel Williams’ fourth album brings new melodic clarity to his kaleidoscopic variations on soft-focus psych pop, pushing his songs into the realm of pure, escapist pleasure.

title: The Station EP
label: Warp
description: Daniel Lopatin’s latest release is less a conceptual follow-up to last month’s Age Of than a gift to hardcore fans who relish even his odds and ends.

title: Best to Ever Do It
label: SODMG
description: Soulja Boy just isn’t able to capitalize on his recent goodwill with some worthwhile new music.

title: The Morning Star
label: Three Lobed
description: No longer content to play music tethered to the past, the Virginia guitarist uses field recordings and unsettling ambient experiments to remake his virtuosic folk compositions for the present.

title: TA13OO
label: Loma Vista
description: The South Florida rapper carves out his own lane within the genre known as SoundCloud rap, displaying considerable versatility as he channels the pain and confusion of youth.

title: Rolling Papers 2
label: Atlantic
description: The latest album from Wiz is a bloated and expensive version of the rap he’s always made but without that signature effortlessness.

title: Porter 2 Grape EP
label: EMPIRE
description: On the first record to appear since 03 Greedo’s incarceration, the L.A. rapper teams up with Vallejo’s Nef the Pharaoh on a breezy five-track EP that makes the most of their respective strengths.

title: Almost
label: Joyful Noise
description: Featuring production assistance from Yoni Wolf of WHY?, the Cincinnati quartet’s second album uses bright surfaces to obscure sinister intentions, clothing dark songs in indie-pop innocence.

title: Sacracorpa
label: Trouble in Mind
description: The final installment in a trilogy of albums by Chicago experimentalist Whitney Johnson gets its motifs from nature and its emotional immediacy from the musician’s recent medical emergency.

title: Collected Acknowledgements
label: Stucco
description: The Olympia punks’ second album presents a chiming, inventive take on post-punk that's shot through with sly humor, madcap time signatures, and wild abandon.

title: Be Yourself EP
label: Tay Bennett Entertainment
description: On his latest project, the Chicago MC deftly explores self-affirmation and paper-chasing without really finding the tension between the two.

title: Here From Where We Are
label: Houndstooth
description: Eight years after releasing his first UK bass single, London’s Arthur Cayzer offers a debut LP of ambient music whose invocation of canonical tropes plays like a love letter to the resurgent genre.

title: Marlowe
label: Mello Music Group
description: On their first collaborative album, Seattle producer L’Orange and North Carolina rapper Solemn Brigham craft spirited, old-school rap that owes a hefty debt to Madvillain.

title: Hive Mind
label: Columbia
description: The fourth album from the R&B collective is a peak example of their combined powers. It simplifies their sound with soft-focus blues, plush arrangements, and deep-in-the-ground grooves.

title: Demur EP
label: Flumo
description: Cleveland producer Warren Harris pushes the deep house sound into rhythmical challenges and brilliantly gothic alcoves with the apparent nonchalance of someone barely breaking a sweat.

title: The Order of Change
label: Music From Memory
description: Amsterdam label Music From Memory continues its revival of late-20th-century Mediterranean sounds with this collection of works by Spanish multi-instrumentalist Suso Sáiz's eclectic ’80s new age trio.

title: Harlan & Alondra
label: RCA
description: The debut from versatile Compton rapper offers a perspective that is close enough to suffer turbulence but removed enough to avoid succumbing to it.

title: Third
label: No Quarter
description: The guitarist’s latest album features almost nothing but the sweet sounds of his instrument. You’ll know within its opening notes whether this music is for you—and if it is, you’ll feel instantly at home.

title: Tru
label: Exploding in Sound
description: On their first album in half a decade, Steve Hartlett and his reunited band of fuzz-rockers turn up both the overdrive and the emotion, fortifying tender songs with muscular squall.

title: Cosmo’s Factory
label: Fantasy
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore Creedence Clearwater Revival’s improbable stardom with 1970’s Cosmo’s Factory.

title: New Lows
label: Fool's Gold
description: The debut album from the Queens crew is fiery and kinetic, mining the history of New York rap without coming up with much of anything new.

title: Forever
label: Mixpak
description: Popcaan’s second album is full of faith, joy, and the wealth of his international pop celebrity, but falters when it comes to his idea of romance.

title: Yolk in the Fur
label: Tiny Engines
description: Following a debut steeped in generational aimlessness, the Brooklyn band’s second album thrives on a combination of rock extroversion and frontman John Ross’ hard-won and tenuous new optimism.

title: Joy
label: Drag City
description: Ty Segall and Tim Presley lock into a psychedelic hive mind again for an exciting, wildly varied album made to be combed through and prodded.

title: Devouring Radiant Light
label: Prosthetic
description: The Ohio party animals scale back the turnt-up thrash of their past in favor of nuanced black metal—without losing their feral edge—on their first full-length with vocalist Adam Clemans.

title: Feel My Pain EP
label: SOB X RBE
description: Post-breakout solo releases are supposed to be this-is-my-time proclamations, but the SOB x RBE member’s project feels engineered to bring out his pathos.

title: Single Rider
label: Hardly Art
description: Carissa’s Wierd alum makes her first foray into crowd-pleasing synth pop in an intriguing collaboration with Seattle-based producer SYML.

title: Homotopy to Marie
label: Rotorelief
description: Decades after its release, the industrial innovators’ newly reissued masterpiece sounds as terrifying as ever—and claims its place in history as a bridge between generations of avant-garde art.

title: Filo Loves the Acid
label: Tresor
description: It’s possible that nobody needs another 303 workout, but the Italian producer’s latest album proves that a programmer of his caliber can still wring some ecstasy from the machine.

title: Don’t Mess With Cupid, ‘Cause Cupid Ain’t Stupid
label: трип
description: A compilation from Nina Kraviz’ трип label connects the dots between leftfield techno, acid, and breakneck hardcore, forging an adventurous style evocative of warehouse raves in deepest Siberia.

title: The Roxy July 7, 1978
label: Columbia
description: At turns explosive and intimate, the three-hour-plus show performed at a small club in West Hollywood is a legendary document of how Bruce and the E Street Band could transform their songs on stage.

title: Sculptor
label: Sub Pop
description: On their third record, the indie-folk duo celebrate choices but settle on none.

title: Disambiguation
label: Drawing Room Records
description: On her debut album as Cruel Diagonals, the Oakland experimental musician Megan Mitchell turns samples sourced from ethnomusicological archives into ambient music that’s both expressive and empathetic.

title: Le Renard Bleu EP
label: !K7
description: On her first new release in almost 20 years, Japanese composer Midori Takada joins London-based musician Lafawndah on a short but fascinating multimedia project with mythical overtones.

title: Raw Silk Uncut Wood
label: Latency
description: Laurel Halo’s most ambient—and most linear—record to date swims in mysterious electro-acoustic textures; it marks a departure from her usual mode of thorny, cerebral electronic composition.

title: 鬼島 Ghost Island EP
label: Danse Noire
description: Taiwanese artist Pon blends traditional mythology and instruments with electronic beats and cacophonous samples on a release inspired by life in—and the urge to escape from—her home city of Taipei.

title: Still Run
label: Columbia
description: The alt-R&B duo’s second album remains preoccupied with breakups, but these stories of separation and loss are rendered so dispassionately, it’s hard to feel invested in their outcomes.

title: Power
label: Tri Angle
description: The debut from the Berlin-based producer explores at the idea of power in the world and within themself, tiptoeing the line between exuberance and terror.

title: Lamp Lit Prose
label: Domino
description: Dave Longstreth is on a madcap quest for personal and political salvation on his latest album, reviving a more hopeful, chipper kind of songwriting of his past.

title: Heart 2 Say
label: Different
description: Singer Rosita Bonita and producer Prinz George prove R&B can still be crazy, sexy, cool on a mixtape that favors the uptempo ’90s grooves of Timbaland, New Edition, and especially TLC.

title: Fink
label: Double Double Whammy
description: Evolving from the lo-fi sound of his home recordings, the New York singer-songwriter significantly steps up his studio chops, but his songs’ emotional register often remains frustratingly oblique.

title: 400 Degreez
label: Cash Money
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the rise of Cash Money on Juvenile’s 1998 classic 400 Degreez.

title: Closer Apart
label: Hyperdub
description: The mostly solid debut album from the South African producer Okzharp and vocalist Manthe Ribane foregoes their earlier sound for something slower and more ponderous.

title: Trouble Anyway
label: Scissor Tail
description: Philadelphia singer-songwriter Rosali Middleman constructs verdant, contemplative rock songs whose soft exteriors conceal a steely core of cool observations about heartache and vulnerability.

title: Death Lust
label: Captured Tracks
description: The proudly suburban Ontario band’s first album uses styles as different as indie pop, shoegaze, and post-hardcore to dramatize frontman Brandon Williams’ journey from despair to rage to resilience.

title: DJ-Kicks
label: !K7
description: DJ Seinfeld’s entry to the long-running mix series is a competent mix of ambient and deep house for the fledgling selector.

title: Sundays
label: Company Records
description: San Francisco musician Hannah Van Loon marries the dreamlike eeriness of the weekend’s final hours with the heaviness of shoegaze on a debut album co-written and produced by Toro Y Moi’s Chaz Bear.

title: Dissidentova
label: AGF Producktion
description: The German experimental musician Antye Greie pays tribute to 16 Russian dissidents, putting cut-up vocals, electronic sound, and collective practice in the service of feminist revolution.

title: The Switch
label: Matador
description: On their most purposeful record to date, Kim Gordon and Bill Nace conjure a complete sonic ecosystem where they control the weather.

title: Ordinary Corrupt Human Love
label: Anti-
description: The most extreme thing about Deafheaven’s remarkable fourth album is how subdued it sounds. It suggests devastation without placing you at the center of it.

title: Supreme Blientele
label: Griselda
description: The ascendent Buffalo rapper combines ’90s boom-bap and a love of wrestling for his latest, which features Anderson .Paak, Busta Rhymes, and more

title: Adepta
label: Fade to Mind
description: Every second of Brooklyn-based DJ and producer Brian Friedberg’s debut album is a cacophony, with sounds that range from Bible-verse vocal samples to foghorns to the tinkling of shattered glass.

title: The Choice
label: Young Turks
description: On a bonus album originally hidden inside gatefold copies of his opus Heaven and Earth, the saxophonist explores his mellower side without breaking any significantly new ground.

title: Pale Lemon
label: Ghost Ramp
description: As recently as last year, So Stressed were a ferocious post-hardcore trio. Now, inspired by the contentment love brings, they make blithe, breezy, and unapologetically melodic pop music.

title: Wandelaar
label: Queeste
description: The debut release on Dutch label Queeste is everything you could wish for in an ambient soundtrack to humid midsummer nights, its melodies as graceful as a swallow’s arc.

title: Vol. 5
label: Yung Bans
description: On his latest project, the Atlanta rapper struggles to break the mold while searching for vulnerability with middling results.

title: Byen
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: After abandoning leftfield disco for a more eclectic brand of weirdness a decade ago, the producer revisits the space disco sounds that made him one of Norway’s original house innovators.

title: BEASTMODE 2
label: Epic
description: The newly vulnerable Future and the hyper-expressive Zaytoven offer up a sequel that doesn’t just reprise the original’s magic but improves on it.

title: Legends of the Summer EP
label: Maybach Music Group
description: The Philadelphia rapper’s first project out of prison is a quick and powerful Meek sampler: the bustling street anthem, the croon-assisted sex jam, the tortured flashback.

title: Valley of Search
label: Valley of Search
description: A 1974 recording from a largely forgotten downtown artist loft space captures some fierce players putting their talents toward a questing, incandescent strain of jazz.

title: Dude, the Obscure
label: Normaltown Records
description: The former Dead Confederate frontman surveys his tangled personal history and uncertain future on a Southern glam rock album that is the highlight of a frustrating career.

title: LP
label: Spectrum Spools
description: Ren Schofield continues to straddle noise and techno on his fourth album, pushing his ramshackle rave music to its breaking point.

title: Uniform Distortion
label: ATO
description: Information overload and its discontents inspire a guitar-heavy solo album that sounds more like a classic My Morning Jacket record than anything James’ band has released in the past 15 years.

title: Ignis EP
label: Cosmo Rhythmatic
description: On the second album to result from a three-year collaboration between late electronic pioneer Mika Vainio and French composer Franck Vigroux, the most striking moments are also the most elemental.

title: I’ll Tell You What!
label: Planet Mu
description: On his first album of all new material, the Chicago footwork pioneer pushes at the outline of the genre, playing with convention and keeping listeners thrillingly off balance.

title: Divine Weight
label: NON Worldwide
description: In what is essentially a radical remix project, the artist formerly known as Dirty Beaches refines his own imperfect saxophone recordings into something radiant and pure.

title: Miss America
label: Virgin
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the ecstatic songs on Mary Margaret O’Hara’s cult hit Miss America.

title: Plight & Premonition / Flux & Mutability
label: Gronland
description: A double reissue of late-1980s albums by the Can co-founder and the synth-pop savant finds them laying the groundwork for years of ambient music that would follow.

title: How Many Times Have You Driven By EP
label: Luminelle
description: On her first official release, the 17-year-old songwriting prodigy offers six slickly produced electronic dream pop tracks whose streaks of misery feel discernibly teenage.

title: Palo Santo
label: Polydor
description: The British trio moves beyond the tropical-house Top 40 of their debut on a theatrical, diverse sophomore album that finds frontman Olly Alexander blurring the boundaries between sacred and profane.

title: Bardo for Pablo
label: Stroom
description: On the second part of a planned trilogy of archival anthologies, a long-forgotten Belgian group from the early 1990s emerges as standard-bearers of globe-trotting ambient and psychedelic techno.

title: Electronic Music From the Eighties and Nineties
label: Unseen Worlds
description: A second volume of the Los Angeles composer’s archival work highlights pieces that attempted to bridge academic research with emotional accessibility, with mixed results.

title: God Level
label: Alamo
description: The Los Angeles rapper’s final album before his 20-year sentence is anxious, forlorn, and self-assured—the violence simmers just below its cool and breezy surface.

title: The Graduation
label: Broyal
description: The debut from the amazing, helium-huffing Atlanta rapper features production from Brodinski and a grip of other European producers that makes it a standout among the city’s rising stars.

title: Seastones
label: Round
description: An expanded new mix of an overlooked, misunderstood 1975 electronic “biomusic” opus—featuring mysterious contributions from Jerry Garcia, David Crosby, Phil Lesh, and others—finally gives the record its due.

title: High as Hope
label: Republic
description: Another relatively stripped-down album featuring the titanic voice of Florence Welch is troubled by its overwhelmingly beige production.

title: I’m All Ears
label: Transgressive
description: The second album from the UK duo is future-pop at its best: kaleidoscopic production and incisive lyrics that swirl into marvelous, breathtaking songs.

title: Topdown Dialectic
label: Peak Oil
description: The anonymous artist’s rustling, swirling ambient techno is as immediate and enveloping as anything leftfield electronic music has produced this year.

title: Sixth House
label: Merge
description: In the 1990s, the Georgia underdogs influenced a generation of indie rockers with their theatrical, reverb-soaked anthems. Nearly two decades later, their first reunion album is more than a throwback.

title: Desolation
label: 20 Buck Spin
description: The Denver doom metal band’s third album is streamlined, expansive, and melodically sharp.

title: Intra
label: Boomkat Editions
description: Mark Fell enlists Portugal’s Drumming Grupo de Percussão to perform captivating computer-generated rhythms on the sixxen, a little-known invention of Iannis Xenakis.

title: All the Things That I Did and All the Things That I Didn’t Do
label: Anti-
description: After years of making somber, traditionalist folk on dueling acoustic guitars, Kenneth Pattengale and Joey Ryan expand their palette on the duo’s most engaging and diverse record to date.

title: Scorpion
label: Young Money Entertainment
description: Drake’s fifth proper studio album is richly produced, studded with gems, and grapples with his fatherhood in a way that casts his arrested development into sharp relief.

title: Incesticide
label: DGC
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the radical underbelly of Nirvana’s 1992 compilation Incesticide.

title: Both Directions at Once: The Lost Album
label: Impulse!
description: The newly discovered, unreleased album from 1963 featuring the “classic quartet” finds the jazz giant thrillingly caught between shoring up and surging forth.

title: Errorzone
label: Closed Casket Activities
description: Yesterday’s Active Rock playlist gets ransacked and reconfigured on the debut full-length from a Boston hardcore quintet whose influences range from Converge to Korn.

title: Hello It’s Me
label: Arrowhawk
description: The comedian, actor, musician, and professional personality recounts a miserable breakup with disarming sincerity and grim humor on a solo debut steeped in rock history.

title: Sink Ya Teeth
label: Hey Buffalo
description: Maria Uzor and Gemma Cullingford channel ESG, Liquid Liquid, and New Order but surpass mere genre mimicry on a debut album that captures the feeling as well as the sounds of classic dance music.

title: The Now Now
label: Parlophone
description: The allure of isolation defines Damon Albarn’s latest project. With only a few guests on the album, he writes simple, mostly upbeat songs with words of exhaustion.

title: Passwords
label: HUB
description: On their sixth album, the Los Angeles rockers attempt to reach across the political spectrum, but their noble intentions clash with cloying lyrics and worn-out arrangements.

title: Zebra
label: Mexican Summer
description: With a large group of collaborators, Alexis Georgopoulos has crafted a pulsing, eclectic, wonderfully breezy album of ethereal psychedelia.

title: Joytime II
label: Marshmello
description: On his second album, the quasi-anonymous DJ in a stylized marshmallow mask proves the perfect figurehead for a commercial EDM scene running on fumes.

title: Freddie
label: ESGN
description: Freddie feels like a pure and reckless purge from Gibbs, a collection that finds him at his wildest and most essential.

title: Renaissance Man
label: Lex
description: The Bronx rapper’s second album in two months has the intimacy of voicemails to a close friend and the warmth of Lil B in his most generous BasedGod form.

title: Year of the Snitch
label: Third Worlds
description: The prolific noise rap project drills down on their sonic signature and remains politically agnostic and persistently agitated.

title: Love Junction
label: Friends of Friends
description: The past decade of British club music looms large on Lorenzo Calpini’s breezy debut album, which enlists a global cast of guest vocalists to broaden the Rome-based producer’s sound.

title: Come to Canada You Will Like It
label: Verdicchio
description: On an album meant to strike “a balance between rural and city living,” the Canadian producer evokes rural idyll in dozy deep house, but the mood too often verges on soporific.

title: Hawaiki Tapes
label: Umor Rex
description: Recorded on the humble Korg Volca FM during a vacation on the Big Island of Hawaii, this atmospheric, unobtrusive album lives somewhere between landscape sketch and spiritual sojourn.

title: Wet Will Always Dry
label: TERNESC
description: The UK techno titan’s debut album is a display of his sound-design prowess—as well as a reminder that even the heaviest techno needn’t shy from the pleasures of weirdo pop.

title: Best Kids
label: Amazon Music
description: Bethany Cosentino and Bobb Bruno recapture the dizzy exuberance that drew audiences to their early singles—but trade the weed for ice cream—on their first foray into kids’ music.

title: K.T.S.E.
label: G.O.O.D. Music
description: Teyana Taylor and her tremendous voice are so deft at performing modernist soul with the genre’s forebears as her backdrop, and her album features some of the best Old Kanye beats heard this year.

title: 200% Galcher
label: Lustwerk Music
description: Five years after his breakthrough mixtape, the former upstart has become a veteran. On his second album in eight months, the rough edges give way to the assured pleasures of an expert in his zone.

title: Lord of Lords
label: Superior Viaduct
description: Alice Coltrane’s newly reissued Lord of Lords capped off a trio of richly orchestral albums in the early ’70s. It is a slow-building, cosmic, unnerving throbbing organism of sound.

title: International Artist
label: Highbridge
description: The latest project from the Bronx rapper enlists musicians from across the globe for an attempted cross-cultural exchange of Afrobeat, dancehall, and reggaeton to mixed effect.

title: Simple Answers
label: Last Things
description: The Psalm Zero frontman and Zs alum reckons with the rise of fascism—and his internal struggle against its insidious appeal—on a debut solo album of unusually confrontational modern classical music.

title: Heaven’s Only Wishful EP
label: Don’t Guess
description: Toronto musician Seth Nyquist’s versatile voice soars on every track of an inviting debut that spans a surprising array of genres and techniques.

title: Dies Iræ Xerox
label: Dial
description: The Rhode Island native’s second album of noisy, downbeat techno is a cocoon ringed with razor wire—the kind of music that’s perfect for headphones and subway journeys when you’re in a foul mood.

title: Kazuashita
label: 4AD
description: On their first album in seven years, the New York fusionists tap into a welter of global styles; the result is soft-edged and idyllic, yet hides a subtle political undercurrent.

title: для FOR
label: Rvng Intl.
description: The Russian electronic musician Kate NV’s sonic portrait of her native Moscow is surreal, otherworldly, and playfully inscrutable.

title: To Record Only Water for Ten Days
label: Warner Bros.
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the haunting and beautiful 2001 solo album from the Red Hot Chili Peppers’ John Frusciante.

title: Redemption
label: Top Dawg
description: After a life-threatening motorcycle accident, Jay Rock returns with his strongest album yet, a collection of rap songs that highlight his struggle and journey.

title: Bad Witch
label: The Null Corporation
description: Trent Reznor’s third EP-length NIN release in the last two years is the best of the lot, with a raw and rough sound that feels both unfinished and alive.

title: Post Traumatic
label: Warner Bros.
description: On his debut solo album, the Linkin Park rapper and producer mourns the death of his bandmate Chester Bennington but never translates that grief into candid lyrics or inspired songwriting.

title: Babelsberg
label: Rough Trade
description: The Super Furry Animals frontman has always been political, but he’s never sounded as spiteful as he does on this satirical portrait of the United States in 2018.

title: Heaven and Earth
label: Young Turks
description: The latest from the saxophonist and bandleader is a multi-genre feast of musical ideas, his most sweeping and complete statement yet.

label: Cash Money
description: The 24-year-old Cash Money singer upcycles ’90s R&B hits on an album of charmingly naughty sex jams—but his referential style is more than just a schtick.

title: June
label: Thrill Jockey
description: In the 37-minute piece that comprises his first solo album since 2005, the Mountains multi-instrumentalist ditches the distractions of the attention economy to luxuriate in a stream of consciousness.

title: Lower East Suite Part Three
label: Big Dada
description: The finale of the New York jazz ensemble’s Lower East Suite trilogy marks a shift in tone and finds the band newly focused.

title: Moodie EP
label: Sub Pop
description: The multi-talented Floridian musician flaunts his 2000s indie and emo influences on a debut EP of perky pop that chronicles a post-breakup transformation.

title: Déjàvu
label: Matty Unlimited
description: A breakdown that led BADBADNOTGOOD keyboardist Matty Tavares to move in with his parents also resulted in this breezy, psychedelic soft-rock album recorded with sought-after sample maker Frank Dukes.

title: Nasty
label: Sugar Trap
description: The ferocious 21-year-old shapeshifter comes through with one of the hardest rap records of the year.

title: Call the Comet
label: New Voodoo
description: The former Smiths guitarist absorbs the political shocks of 2016 on a characteristically polished album that imagines life in an alternate universe that values kindness, curiosity, and intelligence.

title: Sorpresa Familia
label: Captured Tracks
description: Label woes finally resolved, the Catalonian quartet gets its frustrations off its chest on its third album, showcasing a newfound maturity of songcraft without sacrificing youthful energy.

title: Nothing Is Still
label: Ninja Tune
description: After two albums of jazzy, humid club cuts, the British producer moves beyond the dancefloor with a stunning concept record about his grandparents that incorporates ambient and modern classical music.

title: Bon Voyage
label: Fat Possum
description: Six years and one nearly fatal accident after her promising debut, French singer-songwriter Melody Prochet celebrates her recovery with an album of gleefully overstuffed psych-pop.

title: Nasir
label: Mass Appeal
description: No longer able to summon his mythical sense of storytelling, Nas sounds lost on his 11th studio album. Kanye’s production doesn’t help, either.

title: Liberation
label: RCA
description: The pop survivor shows off her powerhouse voice, dabbles in try-hard slang, and takes tentative steps toward creative rebirth on her first album since 2012.

title: Ecstatic Arrow
label: Fire
description: On their third album of avant-garde synth pop, Alice Merida Richards and Sam Pillay eschew protest language and the depressing status quo to conjure a vision of feminist utopia.

title: Cloud Corner
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On her Thrill Jockey debut, the solo guitarist creates truly borderless music, fusing the diverse global traditions she favors without drawing too much attention to the act of juxtaposition.

title: Collagically Speaking
label: Blue Note
description: Jazz pianist Robert Glasper assembles an all-star cast in search of a sound that might reflect the tenor of the times; the meditative results are shaded by politics without wallowing in it.

title: Everything Is Love
label: S.C. Enterprises
description: The Carters round out a trilogy of confrontational albums about their marriage with something lighter but no less resonant. It is a celebration of resilient black love and proud black extravagance.

title: Home Boy, Sister Out
label: Wewantsounds
description: This long-forgotten 1985 album is far from the legendary jazz trumpeter’s best work, but look past its awkwardness and dated sonics, and a certain charm reveals itself.

title: Make My Bed EP
label: Zelig Records
description: On a debut EP that occupies a space between the cathartic stadium pop of fun. and the vulnerability of Lorde, the young singer-producer offers the kind of love songs generations of queer kids craved.

title: Head Over Heels
label: Big Beat
description: On their bona fide all-stars album, everyone from DRAM to Amber Mark to The-Dream cannot save the electronic duo from their tastelessness.

title: New Bodies
label: Temporary Residence
description: The Australian instrumentalists have always used their breathtaking technical dexterity to craft songs that feel like little worlds. Their fourth album fills those spaces with emotion.

title: Super Fly
label: Curtom
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the political soul of Curtis Mayfield’s 1972 album Super Fly.

title: The Graduate (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Sony Legacy
description: Featuring Simon & Garfunkel’s studious folk and the easy listening of Dave Grusin, a new vinyl reissue attests that what makes a fascinating artifact does not always make for an especially good listen.

title: Stranger Fruit
label: MVKA Music
description: Manuel Gagneux’s latest provocative mix of black metal and Southern folk and gospel music is an absurd union that provides moments of vitality and stark political statements about race in America.

title: Come Tomorrow
label: RCA
description: The long-running jam band’s ninth album centers on hard-earned optimism but smooths out much of what makes Dave Matthews’ music engaging.

title: Hereditary (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Milan
description: The saxophonist’s soundtrack to the unsettling horror movie feeds off his darkest impulses as a composer, amplifying and mirroring the trauma and fear on the screen.

title: Consolation EP
label: Domino
description: The four-song EP from the Michigan post-punk band features Kelley Deal of the Breeders and some of the most pointed and impactful songwriting of their career.

title: Devotion
label: Chapter
description: The Australian folk-turned-pop singer revisits her eccentric, romantically unfulfilled teen years on an album that reaches for the coming-of-age immediacy of artists like Lorde and Taylor Swift.

title: OIL OF EVERY PEARL’s UN-INSIDES
label: Transgressive
description: The experimental music of SOPHIE relaxes into new forms on her debut album. It is sprawling and beautiful, while still keeping the disorienting, latex-pop feel of her fascinating production technique.

title: Hope Downs
label: Sub Pop
description: The “120 Minutes” revivalists trade manic exuberance for panicked agitation on a debut album that applies their infectious brand of motorik jangle rock to lovelorn ruminations and geopolitical laments.

title: Showtime EP
label: XL
description: On his first release for the iconic British label XL, the Swedish deep house trickster leans into his pop proclivities and heavy-lidded Lothario persona.

title: Mental Wounds Not Healing
label: Sacred Bones
description: Extreme-metal titans and prolific collaborators the Body team with New York-based industrial duo Uniform on a brutally satisfying—and surprisingly melodic—joint album.

title: Remain in Light
label: Kravenworks
description: Inspired by its Afrobeat underpinnings, the Beninese singer tackles an album-length cover of the Talking Heads’ 1980 landmark, in the process unearthing hidden rhythmic and emotional nuances.

title: The Midnight Hour
label: Linear Labs
description: The two rap-and-soul fusionists aim for a retro aesthetic imbued with the intimacy of a basement club; the results are reminiscent of their Harlem Renaissance-inspired Luke Cage soundtrack.

title: soil
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Taking full advantage of his voluminous, one-of-a-kind voice, experimental pop artist serpentwithfeet offers complex visions of queer love on his debut album.

title: IRISIRI
label: Pan
description: On her third album, the Queens experimental musician explores the way women’s voices can challenge the norms of taste and decorum and push past the boundaries of accepted musical language.

title: Bruce Wayne
label: 300 Entertainment
description: The 28-minute EP continues Fetty Wap’s steady decline from promising trap balladeer to one-dimensional chant rapper.

title: No Shame
label: Warner Bros.
description: Pilloried in the press for her every misfortune, Lily Allen scrutinizes her public persona on an album that dilutes staggering sincerity with uninspired beats.

title: so sad so sexy
label: RCA
description: With festival-ready hooks and trap-inspired production, Lykke Li delivers another record about an unraveling romance and the fraught sexuality of its final moments with diminishing returns.

title: Lost & Found
label: FAMM
description: The precocious 20-year-old singer fuses R&B, soul, and trip-hop on a debut album that documents her ongoing quest to discover who she is and how she fits into a troubled world.

title: Constant Image
label: Domino
description: As D.C. punks with ties to Priests, Fugazi, and Comet Ping Pong, Flasher are expected to have something to say about politics in 2018—but their debut album would have felt just as timely 30 years ago.

title: Roach Goin’ Down
label: Wharf Cat
description: The offbeat New York trio’s wicked sense of humor shines on an album of punchy, peculiar songs that register as pleasant and uncomfortable at once.

title: Whack World
label: self-released
description: The surreal, audiovisual album from the Philadelphia artist is only 15 minutes long, but it is overflowing with hooks and a powerful sense of imagination.

title: Kids See Ghosts
label: G.O.O.D. Music
description: The psychic bond between Kanye and Kid Cudi yields a spacious and melancholy album about brokenness—thoughts are fragmented, relationships are ended, and societal ties are cut.

title: Insula
label: Hyperdub
description: Still a child during grime’s original heyday, the Edinburgh producer approaches the genre with a collagist’s appreciation for layering, juxtaposition, and hyper-referentiality.

title: Childqueen
label: Fat Possum
description: The psych-soul singer summons the confidence and exuberance of childhood on an immersive sophomore album.

title: Shannon in Nashville
label: Easy Eye Sound
description: The gale-force frontwoman of Shannon and the Clams collaborates with producer Dan Auerbach on a sparkling debut solo album that sounds like Roy Orbison lost in the Brill Building.

title: The Band
label: Capitol
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the collectivism of the Band’s 1969 self-titled album.

title: An ASMR Album
label: Nice Life
description: The extremely online 25-year-old comedian’s foray into a more traditional comedy format makes for an imposing and uneven listen, even for the most logged-on.

title: 3rd Ward Bounce EP
label: Asylum
description: The bounce queen’s latest EP marks her return to the unctuous, mechanized mother tongue of New Orleans.

title: Kicker EP
label: Polyvinyl
description: After nearly 20 years of playing against their strengths, the Get Up Kids jump on the “adult emo” bandwagon and recapture the punk immediacy of their late-’90s heyday.

title: Lightlessness Is Nothing New
label: Barsuk
description: After a six-year hiatus, the Chicago math-rock-turned-pop-rock act returns with a deceptively upbeat album inspired by the death of singer-guitarist Dave Davison’s father.

title: Listening to Pictures (Pentimento Volume One)
label: Ndeya
description: On his first album in nine years, the Los Angeles trumpeter-composer sounds like he’s remixing himself, taking apart his past 40 years of work and reassembling it for the present moment.

title: Our Raw Heart
label: Relapse
description: The long-running Oregon doom metal trio opens its third act with a sensuous, aggressive, and jubilant album inspired by singer-guitarist Mike Scheidt's recent brush with death.

title: Lush
label: Matador
description: Snail Mail’s striking debut album is emotionally wise, musically clear, and encompasses the once and future sound of indie rock.

title: Both
label: Heavy Body
description: King Krule collaborator Kaya Wilkins escapes music-industry servitude and speaks truth on her own terms in a frank, often melancholy bedroom-pop debut leavened by diaristic sarcasm.

title: LUMP
label: Dead Oceans
description: On their first collaborative album, Laura Marling and Tunng’s Mike Lindsay wrap prickly observations about lifestyle consumerism in bales of gorgeous melody and grumbling dissonance.

title: Stereo EP
label: self-released
description: The Indiana singer-songwriter brings his seductive falsetto and clever production touches to a short, sweet debut EP of bedroom pop and throwback soul.

title: Strata EP
label: Once In A Blue Moon
description: Named after an architectural icon looming over South East London, the rapper’s six-track EP offers a detailed account of life at the building’s base.

title: Prequelle
label: Loma Vista
description: Unmasked in 2017 as Ghost’s mastermind, Tobias Forge trades in his papal regalia for a new persona on a darkly comic album that is lots of fun despite its flaws.

title: The Future and the Past
label: ATO
description: The singer-songwriter follows up her gloriously baroque debut with an album that uses deep grooves, politicized self-portraiture, and an eye for everyday cruelty to reckon with life in the Trump era.

title: Still EP
label: Rhymes of an Hour
description: The dream-pop legends breathe new life into old songs on a slight, unsurprising, but reliably lovely EP of dreamy desert blues.

title: Streams of Thought, Vol. 1
label: Human Re Sources
description: After 30 years fronting the Roots, Black Thought has finally put out his first solo EP. It is rigorous but rarely hermetic, a small testament to his sustained excellence.

title: You, Forever
label: Saddle Creek
description: Celestial Shore singer-guitarist Sam Owens puts his own actions and desires under a microscope on a gentle, sunny, yet boldly honest solo album.

title: Patina Echoes
label: Timedance
description: Released by UK bass scion Batu, this survey of cutting-edge club music is less a collection of voices than a shared statement of purpose, full of thrilling rhythms and textures.

title: Winning Star Champion
label: Barsuk
description: Seattle indie scene veteran Matt Batey contrasts bouncy power-pop with lyrics about anxiety and failure on his cathartic solo debut for Barsuk.

title: Sacrifices
label: Lex
description: Returning to his best-known alias, the veteran hip-hop deconstructionist scales back his approach, but Sacrifices can feel slight, with songs that too often fade into the background.

title: Assimilation
label: Where to Now?
description: Fresh off a thrilling collaboration with Joy Orbison, the British saxophonist teams with Mica Levi, Rupert Clervaux, and others on an audacious solo album that feels like another team effort.

title: Hell-On
label: Anti-
description: On her self-produced seventh solo LP, Neko Case brings on a bunch of collaborators for a dense album that searches for connection amid human cruelty and chaos.

title: ye
label: G.O.O.D. Music
description: Kanye West’s stint in Wyoming created an album born from chaos for chaos’ sake. Though it can be somewhat fascinating, it is undoubtedly a low point in his career.

title: The Long Sleep
label: Sacred Bones
description: The experimental songwriter abandons the conceptual rigor of her recent albums, collaborating with a handful of jazz musicians on a loose, ambiguous EP where repetition induces a state of déjà vu.

title: Wildness
label: Polydor
description: On his band's first album in seven years, Gary Lightbody aims for clarity, connection, and personal resonance but lapses into the pomp and incoherence that have plagued Snow Patrol for a decade.

title: Deeper
label: Fire Talk
description: The Chicago quartet’s debut is well-oiled and worn-in indie rock, played with the precision and confidence typically expected from a band much further along in its career.

title: Live Through This
label: City Slang
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the righteous anger of Hole’s 1994 album Live Through This.

title: Return of the Frog Queen
label: Sub Pop
description: The Sunny Day Real Estate leader's 1996 solo debut is often viewed through the prism of his Christian rebirth. Sub Pop's reissue reveals how its orchestral grandeur helped shape indie rock's future.

title: Age Of
label: Warp
description: The tenth album from Daniel Lopatin is his most collaborative and accessible solo project to date, yet still full of unexpected chaos and songs that can suddenly dissolve and disarm.

title: Lush Life
label: Mysteries of Trade
description: The Toronto duo follows up an eight-year-old debut EP with an album that gestures toward various eras of dancehall and traverses a range of emotion.

title: Dream House
label: Innervisions
description: The Berlin tech-house duo’s debut album purports to expand its palette, but an impressive list of collaborators can’t keep the music from lapsing into middle-of-the-road anonymity.

title: Skulls Example
label: Orindal
description: Katy Davidson’s indie-folk project returns on an album that mines philosophical poetry from moments when ancient natural wonders meet modern technology.

title: Cruel Practice
label: NUXXE
description: On her debut EP, South East London singer and DJ Blane Muise combines venomous lyricism with tar-boiling industrial beats to inhabit a fierce, sexual, pathologically impatient, and deeply cathartic alter ego.

title: Goodbye & Good Riddance
label: Grade A
description: Juice WRLD’s emo-rap debut is an adolescent breakup record that is equal parts endearing and grating.

title: God’s Favorite Customer
label: Sub Pop
description: Josh Tillman is still self-absorbed. But his fourth full-length as Father John Misty exhibits a new sense of empathy and vulnerability while losing none of his wit.

title: Cave Vaults of the Moon
label: Séance Centre
description: The Taos composer’s 1987 accompaniment to a sculpture exhibition with a sci-fi bent makes for a synth-heavy adventure in new age that’s by turns eerie and playful.

title: V.
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The dyed-in-the-wool psych-rock band returns with some of their most accessible songs to date, full of fuzz-pedal jams that capture moments of fleeting happiness in dark days.

title: Diary 001 EP
label: Fader
description: The lo-fi pop singer’s first label release is an EP whose careful songwriting and intriguingly flat vocals should quiet naysayers who dismissed her as a one-hit fluke.

title: Vibras
label: Universal Music Latino
description: The reggaetonero’s latest sets him up for even more global success. Its infectious vibe is draped in dancehall with a dash of trap production and nods to salsa, bachata, and Afrobeat.

title: Shawn Mendes
label: Island
description: On his third album, the former Vine star grows into a persona that’s playful, gently libidinous, and safely menace-free, but his music too often falls on the wrong side of beige.

title: Love Is Dead
label: Glassnote
description: With help from some outside producers, Chvrches’ try to launch themselves into the mainstream. The result is an uncomplicated, unsurprising collection of steely synth pop.

title: cc EP
label: self-released
description: After last year’s Tommy EP, the South London electronic musician turns her abstracted sound collages to more pointedly cathartic ends: complex music that brims with conflicting emotions.

title: Medicaid Fraud Dogg
label: C Kunspyruhzy
description: On their first album in 38 years, George Clinton and his impressive band channel the Parliament of old for something decidedly modern. It’s delightfully raunchy but also surprisingly tenderhearted.

title: Tracyanne & Danny
label: Merge
description: Five years after Camera Obscura’s last album, Tracyanne Campbell returns with a new musical partner and a more mannered, slightly cautious sound, but her voice is as singular as ever.

title: Sink EP
label: Stones Throw
description: The genre-defying violinist levels up as a songwriter on an EP of experimental pop and R&B. It explodes conventional musical logic with disarming ease.

title: Paz & Amor EP
label: Príncipe Discos
description: The Lisbon producer’s solo debut takes the spiky, polyrhythmic sound of Portuguese batida and bends it toward a sleek dancefloor sensibility, making for Príncipe’s most accessible release yet.

title: Midnight Marker
label: Beats in Space
description: On Shy Layers’ second album, his chill-but-adventurous aesthetic snaps into clearer focus. Highlife, funk, Ethio-jazz, and more all swirl together in every measure of music.

title: Testing
label: RCA
description: On his third studio album, Rocky is more experimental and personal. But for music that relies on the New York rapper’s artful intuitions, it’s unfortunate his intuitions are often very basic.

title: Black Soap
label: Lex
description: The 19-year-old rapper’s latest project is a quest of self-discovery that serves as a reminder of the power and dexterity New York’s new vanguard of artists.

title: Only Built 4 Cuban Linx
label: Loud
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore Raekwon’s game-changing 1995 debut Only Built 4 Cuban Linx.

title: Uptown Festival / Disco Gardens / Big Fun
label: Robinsongs
description: The first three records from the R&B group that came out of “Soul Train” show their evolution from a schmaltzy cash-grab to a bona fide bringer of disco joy.

title: Big Wave More Fire
label: Loma Vista
description: The LA-based electronic duo that gave Kanye’s The Life of Pablo its gospel-house sheen embraces pop on an album featuring guest vocals by Amber Mark, Khalid, and The-Dream.

title: Sugar & Spice EP
label: Double Double Whammy
description: On her well-formed debut EP, Harriette Pilbeam's version of dream pop is more pop than dream.

title: Puff LP: In the air without a shape
label: Arts & Crafts
description: Pop and R&B melodies meet shambling, C86-style song structures on the eclectic Toronto band’s first album since 2011.

title: Themes for Television
label: Italians Do It Better
description: The surprise release collects unheard material originally meant for “Twin Peaks: The Return”; though slighter than this year’s Digital Rain EP, it might be Jewel’s strongest soundtrack work yet.

title: The Return
label: Black Focus
description: Following the dissolution of the jazz-funk duo Yussef Kamaal, the London keyboardist returns with an urbane, dynamic album that’s deeply rooted in the city’s rhythms.

title: (((echo chamber)))
label: Mello Music Group
description: On his first album in nearly a decade, the absurdist rapper uses his enormous vocabulary to riff on race, class, and becoming a parent—but he still hasn’t outgrown of fart jokes.

title: Daytona
label: G.O.O.D. Music
description: Produced entirely by Kanye West, the spare and serrated solo album from Pusha-T is a near-airtight exercise in flair and focus.

title: Perfume EP
label: Drag City
description: Cory Hanson and his SoCal cohorts continue their transformation from manic garage rockers to shape-shifting innovators on an EP as eclectic as White Light/White Heat.

title: Double Dream of Spring
label: 4AD
description: This limited, tour-only cassette feels spontaneous yet brimming with ideas. It sounds somewhere between ghostly demos and a lo-fi avant-garde ambient composition.

title: Steamroom 40
label: steamroom
description: The 40th installment of the prolific producer and composer’s Steamroom series is a highlight, one long, meditative piece of synth overtones, slowly rising arpeggios, and pure drift.

title: Light of Mine
label: Atlantic
description: The carefree California rapper’s debut is an exceedingly joyous and self-aware slice of pop rap.

title: Love Yourself 轉 ‘Tear’
label: BigHit Entertainment
description: The latest album from the masters of the K-pop formula is a slick, loosely thematic album about love and loss, with a stronger emphasis on rapping than ever before.

title: Reckless
label: XO
description: The Toronto rapper’s debut is a long shot at cementing his legacy that is plagued by indecision and self-doubt.

title: Harder Than Ever
label: Quality Control
description: Lil Baby’s official debut is technically impressive: polished, efficient, but also kind of nondescript.

title: Deeper Woods
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On her third solo album, North Carolina guitarist Sarah Louise Henson steps beyond her vivid acoustic work and into a realm of glowing studio experimentation and layered vocals.

title: Luminosity Device
label: Dynamic Tension
description: Inspired by the Tibetan Book of the Dead, the Birmingham techno producer puts a fresh spin on his pummeling club tracks; the album is equally suited for dancefloor abandon and spiritual searching.

title: Angels of Death
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: The Toronto singer’s album is a country and gospel-infused meditation on death and mourning that flickers between the broadly universal and the devastatingly personal.

title: Tell Me How You Really Feel
label: Mom & Pop
description: Courtney Barnett’s second album is smaller, more introverted than her debut. It’s tentative but with a purpose, songs about what it means to not have—or need—the right words for everything.

title: Yesterday’s Tomorrows
label: Wolf
description: On his third album, Berlin producer Sebastian Genz switches up his dreamy house sound with forays into drum ‘n’ bass and boom-bap hip-hop but can’t shake his nostalgia addiction.

title: Deafman Glance
label: Dead Oceans
description: After several albums of traditional, jazzy folk-rock, the Chicago-based singer-songwriter finds a more instinctive voice.

title: Wax Chattels
label: Captured Tracks
description: Billing itself as a “guitarless guitar band,” the New Zealand noise-rock trio endeavors to make bass, keyboard, and two-piece drum kit sound as loud as possible.

title: Happy Ending
label: Etruscan Gold
description: Wax Idols complete their transformation from sardonic post-punks to theatrical goth-rock storytellers on an album that dares to take pleasure in confronting death.

title: Saved
label: Trans
description: Now, Now trade guitar rock and raw nerves for slick, left-of-center pop on a deceptively upbeat comeback album whose intense lyrics and unsettling sounds stay true to the duo’s emo roots.

title: Wide Awake!
label: Rough Trade
description: On their fourth album, Parquet Courts enlist Danger Mouse to produce an album of joyfully absurd, danceable rock music. It is straightforward but alien, simple but endlessly referential.

title: Spirit in the Dark
label: Atlantic
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore Aretha Franklin’s immensely personal 1970 album Spirit in the Dark.

title: Buck Meek
label: Keeled Scales
description: The debut solo album from the Big Thief guitarist has a quiet and mischevious spirit, with a focus put on his nimble playing and Texas twang.

title: Cannonball!
label: 88rising
description: The Kyoto-born, Chicago-based multi-instrumentalist uses his nonchalant flow and the sharp instincts he acquired playing saxophone as a kid to craft a dynamic, introspective jazz-rap debut.

title: The Album Collection Vol. 2, 1987-1996
label: Columbia
description: The seven albums after Bruce Springsteen’s commercial peak tell a story of lost faith and self-doubt. It’s a darker, messier portrait that still includes one of his essential records.

title: Everything Matters But No One Is Listening
label: Polyvinyl
description: Inspired by his love for Stephin Merritt, James Alex serves up chamber-pop covers of his own earnest punk songs on the first album from this Beach Slang spin-off band.

title: Hundreds of Days
label: Ghostly International
description: The harp innovator experiments with an arsenal of new instruments—including her voice—on an album of ambient music as complex and meditative as the work of Pauline Oliveros.

title: Violet Psalms
label: Paper Bag
description: On what the band has said is its final album, Frog Eyes sound galvanized by the prospect of bowing out, resulting in their strongest record in years.

title: Rausch
label: Kompakt
description: Wolfgang Voigt’s investigations of German heritage turn ominous on an imposing, hour-long ambient album whose title translates as “frenzy”; it feels closely keyed to the current political state.

title: Letters of Irrelevance
label: EMPIRE
description: Following his bandmates Syd, Matt Martians, and Steve Lacy, the bassist of L.A.’s the internet steps up with his solo debut. He’s not yet a natural leader, but his musicianship is self-evident.

title: Sparkle Hard
label: Matador
description: On his fetching seventh solo album, the witty and digressive songwriting of Stephen Malkmus becomes newly and delightfully grounded in the present day.

title: Period
label: Quality Control
description: Rappers JT and Yung Miami give the menstrual cycle top billing on a debut that showcases their synergy but doesn’t deliver the transgressive goods its title promises.

title: To Drink From the Night Itself
label: Century Media
description: The Swedish melodic death metal innovators crib from a career highlight, 1994’s Terminal Spirit Disease, on their first reunion album that does justice to their legacy.

title: Faminine Mystique
label: Nihjgt Feelings
description: The witch-house pioneer and a Berlin-based producer join forces on a purposefully “difficult-to-digest” album whose sprawling array of references and styles mimics life online.

title: Compro
label: Ilian Tape
description: The German producer Brian Müller has a preternatural feel for the dancefloor, and his latest is a shining hybrid of breakbeats and ambient textures, making it one of the best dance records of the year.

title: Die Lit
label: AWGE
description: The Atlanta rapper’s official debut is an album that works almost completely from its own lunatic script. It is a perversely infectious sugar high, rap that fundamentally recalibrates the brain’s reward centers.

title: Failed Celestial Creatures
label: Empty Editions
description: The Gastr del Sol founder melds minds with a Japanese guitarist and electronic musician who shares his skewed approach to songwriting on an album inspired by the work of novelist Atsushi Nakajima.

title: In the Rainbow Rain
label: ATO
description: Will Sheff makes kindness an aesthetic on this album of gentle, idiosyncratic songs about dog adoption, celebrities’ emergency tracheotomies and finding transcendence in nature.

title: Mark Kozelek
label: Caldo Verde
description: The songwriter’s latest great long ode to himself is at once bloated and transcendent, boring and mesmerizing.

title: Kiss Yr Frenemies
label: Tiny Engines
description: Veteran studio rat Sarah Tudzin steps out from behind the boards on a debut album that uses the timeless conventions of indie-pop to capture the experience of being a young adult in 2018.

title: I Have Fought Against It, But I Can’t Any Longer.
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Constructed largely out of cut-up and processed samples of their previous recordings, the noise-metal iconoclasts’ latest album takes the listener on journey through a hell of the Body’s careful making.

title: NORF: The Legend of Hotboy Ronald
label: NewAgeNarcissism
description: On his debut album, the Milwaukee rapper Lorde Fredd33 emerges fully-formed. He is charismatic and nuanced, painting a complex, deeply-personal portrait of black life in America’s rust belt.

title: NTS Sessions 1-4
label: Warp
description: Autechre’s eight-hour NTS Sessions adds another level of the British duo’s legacy. Though it’s created by a computer, it will bring you to another plane of human existence if you let it.

title: O
label: Dero Arcade
description: Cody Critcheloe’s witty multimedia alt-pop project exults in uncensored queerness on an album that fulfills the musician and filmmaker’s maximalist ambitions.

title: Tranquility Base Hotel & Casino
label: Domino
description: Arctic Monkeys’ daring sixth album is a left-turn if ever there was one, but the way Alex Turner swaps witty sleaze for absurdist suave makes it a totally bemusing and fascinating listen.

title: On Watch
label: LandLand
description: The debut from the Chicago post-hardcore group revels in playing with teeth-gritting tension and dynamics, defining their sound by its restraint as much as its rage.

title: Activated
label: 300 Entertainment
description: The Detroit rapper’s debut album aims for a mix of transparency and commercial ambition, but he struggles to hold his own amid so much high-stakes production.

title: Time Out of Mind
label: Columbia
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore Bob Dylan’s masterful comeback, 1997’s Time Out of Mind.

title: Marely Barch
label: Halloween
description: Recorded at home on his mother’s laptop, Barely March’s debut album is a scrappy, tuneful album of post-breakup self-deprecation that recognizes the absurdity of wallowing in your own bullshit.

title: Beware the Book of Eli
label: Victor Victor
description: The South Florida rapper sounds like a hip-hop Hades on a menacing, underworldly mixtape leavened by cracked psychedelia, surreal humor, and straight-up weirdness.

title: Baylor Swift
label: TWIN
description: As its title suggests, the Atlanta rapper’s album is pop-focused and geared for emo. She sounds reborn, retrofitting her scrappy rap with Technicolor pop-punk for songs about overcoming heartbreak.

title: Any Day
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On their first album in six years, the post-rock stalwarts bring new urgency to their signature gliding rhythms, jazz-inflected guitar lines, and analog synth tones.

title: Fall in Love EP
label: Hush Hush
description: On his second solo EP, the Seattle producer weaves together samples, field recordings, and original instrumentation to craft tactile electronic music that’s beat-oriented yet meditative.

label: Sub Pop
description: Beach House remain masters of the indefinable and their seventh album is their heaviest and most immersive-sounding of their career.

title: Murmurations
label: Wichita
description: Simian Mobile Disco team up with all-female singing collective Deep Throat Choir for an adventurous full-length that is their first album to prominently feature vocals in nearly a decade.

title: JP3
label: self-released
