description: On her third album, the New York rapper sounds as joyfully lascivious as ever, but slower and funkier, casting aside trifling men and centering her own self-fulfillment.

title: DNA Feelings
label: Houndstooth
description: The Swiss producer reframes electronic music as a mode of spiritual searching on an album that deemphasizes grooves and lyrics in favor of icy, alien sounds and high, inscrutable cries.

title: Singularity
label: Domino
description: Pitched between heat-seeking acid house and ambient bliss, the techno auteur’s first album since 2013 is a beat-music odyssey that thrums with spiritual resonance.

title: Simi
label: Bloc Nation
description: On the heels of a viral dance and a Drake feature, the Memphis rapper’s latest mixtape is a breakthrough that’s honest, clear, and incredibly fun.

title: Downtown Castles Can Never Block the Sun
label: International Anthem
description: On his debut album, the uncategorizable Chicago musician knits together experimental jazz, funk playfulness, Brazilian rhythms, and the sensuality of Prince.

title: The Horizon Just Laughed
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Two decades into his career, these songs are among the most incisive but somehow most complex ones Jurado has ever written, lined up from end to end without a wasted note, layer, line, or word.

title: Conexão EP
label: PMR
description: The New York singer’s casually elegant EP is remarkably accomplished. Even at just four songs, Amber Mark sounds like a veteran of pop songcraft and performance.

title: L.O.D. EP
label: Def Jam
description: The 21-year-old Kanye West acolyte and Future soundalike tries again to step out of his elders’ shadows on an EP that is unlikely to quiet his critics.

title: Until Death Call My Name
label: Never Broke Again, LLC
description: The 18-year-old Baton Rouge rapper’s debut album is packed with allegories on power that illuminate but don’t apologize for his well-publicized history of violence.

title: Appreciation
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: On Horse Feathers’ sixth album, their introverted persona has thawed, revealing a surprising affinity for the joy of Stax-era and country-fried soul.

title: DOVE
label: Belly Touring
description: On their first album in over 20 years, Tanya Donelly and her band conjure the same potent mix of grace and force that fueled their 1990s output.

title: SR3MM
label: Eardruma
description: The triple album from Slim Jxmmi and Swae Lee is their clearest personal statement yet, a shining triptych of what it looks like to be young, black, and euphoric.

title: Good Thing
label: LisaSawyer63
description: The second, more adventurous album from the Texas soul singer bends toward the present while keeping the warmth of classic R&B in his melodies and songwriting.

title: Mixtape
label: self-released
description: On a mixtape of exclusive material debuted on NTS Radio, the Toronto-based producer Jacques Greene trades distanced, soulful melancholy for full-on dancefloor hypnosis.

title: Music for Installations
label: UMC
description: Though containing music that goes back to 1985, Music For Installations is hardly a retrospective in any traditional sense. It’s more a whimsical line connecting ideas in Eno's own personal Long Now.

title: Starting Today
label: Brownswood
description: This solo debut from a fixture of London’s vital and eclectic jazz community delves into dub, soul, and fusion on a journey from the scene’s diverse roots to its exhilarating present.

title: Beyondless
label: Matador
description: On their astonishing fourth album, the Danish punk band reach for pop-gothic grandeur with more tenacity and abandon than ever.

title: Rejuvenate
label: R&S
description: Danny Brown’s go-to producer abandons his sampledelic style for an album of original beats and inspired guest vocals that reveal who he really is as a solo artist.

title: The Flowers of Romance
label: Virgin
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we offer a first-hand account of the brilliant chaos of PiL’s The Flowers of Romance.

title: Blue Dream EP
label: self-released
description: Dropping the club-centric vibe of his previous work, the New York rapper shifts toward trap and Top 40 rap sounds—an unconventional move that might be more progressive than it seems.

title: Venetian Snares x Daniel Lanois
label: Timesig
description: The ambient guitarist and the breakcore wizard bring diametrically opposed instincts and skill sets to an album that strikes an uneasy balance between calm and chaos.

title: The Good Is a Big God
label: Luaka Bop
description: Working alongside his longtime bandmates Moreno Veloso and Alexandre Kassin, plus the string arranger Sean O’Hagan, the Rio multi-instrumentalist ponders Brazilian music’s rootedness.

title: Lost Friends
label: Domino
description: The Australian trio’s debut album deals in radiant, anthemic indie rock, balancing doubt-ridden lyrics with clear-eyed execution.

title: Chiquito EP
label: self-released
description: The short EP from the California singer showcases his ear for cool sounds, and every track puts his dynamic personality and oddly calibrated synths front and center.

title: Hello People
label: Flemish Eye
description: This lovingly curated posthumous album collects a decade’s worth of unreleased ambient compositions by the late Women guitarist.

title: Anticlines
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Lucrecia Dalt’s sixth album is a marvelous exploration of mercurial ambient music whose aesthetic is so singular, it feels like she dreamed it into being.

title: Rebound
label: Frenchkiss
description: On her fourth solo album, Eleanor Friedberger embraces ’80s goth pop and explores a newly fragmented internal landscape as a post-election expat in Greece.

title: Knock Knock
label: Pampa
description: Listening to Stefan Kozalla’s latest is an essential experience. He finds the moments that express wistful longing, burrows into them, and then blows it all up to color-saturated widescreen.

title: House With a Pool
label: Ghost Ramp
description: The Houston rapper Fat Tony teams with Los Angeles producer Kyle Mabson for a noisy, synth-funk, outré record that often gels together and pushes at the boundaries of experimental rap.

title: Hollow Ground
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Max Clarke balances vintage recording methods with expressive songwriting on the ’60s-style pop ballads that fill his debut album as Cut Worms.

title: Beerbongs & Bentleys
label: Republic
description: The second album from the crossover star features a few inarguable pop hits, but Post Malone’s singular, dour mood wears thin and grows stale after too long.

title: Poo Bear Presents: Bearthday Music
label: Capitol
description: The songwriter extraordinaire lets guests and producers steal his spotlight, making for a pop compilation that is interchangeably chill, spanning every genre at its absolute lowest key.

title: Sway
label: Sony
description: Fascinated by the psychology behind human connection, the Swedish pop singer celebrates all varieties of romantic vulnerability on her exuberant third album.

title: Miro Tape
label: Bokeh Versions
description: The Jamaican vocalists of Sun Araw and M. Geddes Gengras’ Duppy Gun project team with producers from Bristol label Bokeh Versions on a dub mixtape that tests the limits of the genre.

title: Girly-Sound to Guyville: The 25th Anniversary Box Set
label: Matador
description: Liz Phair’s indelible, essential debut album has been reissued with three crucial bedroom tapes that further define the innovative and unselfconscious songwriting from early in her career.

title: DJ Healer: Nothing 2 Loose // Prime Minister of Doom: Mudshadow Propaganda
label: All Possible Worlds
description: The electronic artist of many pseudonyms returns with two complimentary records twinning house and techno within new, broadly ranging, self-contained worlds.

title: With Dim Light
label: Guruguru Brain
description: Krautrock, psychedelia, and a DJ’s flair for track sequencing come together on an album that proves this Tokyo trio is more than just a revival act.

title: Only Love
label: Throat Ruiner
description: The second album from the Detroit hardcore collective is as ambitious as it is effective. Noise, art rock, and a surprising amount of hooks are knotted within their chaotic maximalism.

title: Dirty Computer
label: Atlantic
description: Ever the innovator, Janelle Monáe has crafted a singular, youthful pop record that is the culmination of years of silence and deflection in order to one day be free.

title: Facepaint EP
label: Future Classic
description: Sasha Spielberg reunites with her Just Friends bandmate, Nicolas Jaar, for a somber solo EP that finds the Wardell singer forging an identity of her own.

title: You’re Driving Me Crazy
label: Legacy
description: On his third album in seven months, Morrison teams up with jazz musician Joey DeFrancesco for a collection of originals and standards that captures the joy of making music.

title: Elysia Crampton
label: Break World
description: On her fourth album, Elysia Crampton continues staking out an anti-colonialist conception of time. It blooms from big, propulsive drum patterns while conjuring a sense of profound loneliness.

title: Grid of Points
label: Kranky
description: Liz Harris’ sparse, 22-minute record follows the trajectory of her 2014 album Ruins to a place that feels even more wind-blown and remote.

title: Question and Answer EP
label: The Bunker
description: This brief EP shows just how much ingenuity and fresh new wrinkles Wata Igarashi can wring out of his Roland-909, Ableton, and modular synth set-up.

title: Perfect From Now On
label: Warner Bros.
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore Built to Spill’s winding, monumental 1997 album Perfect From Now On.

title: Gate 13
label: Gate13
description: Protean future-funk production steals the show on this collaboration between two veterans of the Bay Area hip-hop scene.

title: Bloodline
label: Apron
description: The London producer pays tribute to his musical and familial heritage on a sophomore album that makes vintage Roland gear sound new again.

title: Trout Mask Replica
artist: Captain Beefheart and His Magic Band
label: Third Man
description: Captain Beefheart’s 1969 masterpiece set an unmatched standard for avant-rock. This new reissue from Third Man puts it back in print on vinyl.

title: Crop Circle
label: XL
description: The latest album from the star of UK road rap is an entirely new and impressively unconfined sound with Nines still grounding himself firmly in his past.

title: Spaghetti Factory
label: EMPIRE
description: On his latest mixtape, the Atlanta rapper uses his innate charisma and exacting eye for the details of the drug trade to court a national audience that has so far eluded him.

title: Conquistador
label: Sargent House
description: The drone-metal titan’s “imaginary Western” fleshes out his talents as a storyteller, but this album of mostly solo electric guitar doesn’t feel as fully realized as his band Earth’s best work.

title: A Piece of Beyond
label: Subject Detroit
description: The veteran DJ confirms his status as a treasured keeper of Detroit techno’s flame on an album balancing resolute functionality with a subtly psychedelic, expressive dimension.

title: Forth Wanderers
label: Sub Pop
description: The Sub Pop debut from the New Jersey indie rock band arrives refreshingly well-formed. Their music has an urbane sensibility, one that feels not just older in age, but in sound.

title: Twerp Verse
label: Carpark
description: Speedy Ortiz’s third album is wry, acerbic, and full of hidden hooks. The songwriting of singer-guitarist Sadie Dupuis has hit a new peak of clarity.

title: Everywhere at the End of Time - Stage 4
label: History Always Favours the Winners
description: The fourth installment of Leyland Kirby‘s six-part series as the Caretaker is his most visceral album yet, an ambient look at the degradation of music and memory.

title: Sparrow
label: Warner Music Nashville
description: The Nashville singer-songwriter looks backwards to move forward on an album that filters contemporary desires and sorrows through the timeless vernacular of country.

title: The Sciences
label: Third Man
description: The iconic stoner metal band’s first studio album in almost two decades is a twin ode to volume and weed. It makes everything that was originally great about Sleep even better.

title: Not for Sale
label: Babygrande
description: Harlem rapper Smoke DZA keeps it real on Not For Sale, doubling down on classic hip-hop as he’s got an allergy to trends. That’s mostly a good thing.

label: Interscope
description: The reggae-lite collaboration between Sting and Shaggy is as professional, good-natured, and helplessly uncool as its billing promises.

title: Complicit EP
label: GO4 Music
description: The crassly political EP from Andy Gill struggles to capture the power found in the band’s most potent statements.

title: Lavender
label: Cascine
description: A woozy dynamic of pushing people away while simultaneously drawing them close courses throughout Lavender, a striking album of beautifully rendered and deeply layered synth-pop.

title: Primal Heart
label: Warner Bros.
description: The New Zealand musician’s third album is a collision of hard electronics with a touch of R&B. Though it contains moments of great power, it sounds like a work that’s stuck between two places.

title: The Scars of Man on the Once Nameless Wilderness (I and II)
label: Bindrune
description: Minnesota-based musician Austin Lunn splits his love of black metal and Appalachian folk into two distinct halves on this double LP.

title: Sun Go Nova
label: Mello Music Group
description: Detroit rapper Denmark Vessey lives in the haze. His Sun Go Nova is freewheeling and exciting, the kind of hip-hop that breathes.

title: Stargate Music
artist: Ras G & the Afrikan Space Program
label: Leaving
description: The L.A. beatmaker’s 11th release on Leaving Records moves between wobbly R&B loops, musique concrète, stoned sonic detours, and E.T.-friendly G-funk.

title: KOD
label: Dreamville
description: With his fifth album, the North Carolina rapper aims for righteousness but often ends up sounding self-righteous instead.

title: Eat the Elephant
label: BMG
description: On their first album in 14 years, art-metal giants Maynard James Keenan and Billy Howerdel swerve unexpectedly toward gloomy adult-alternative.

title: Hippo Lite
label: Drag City
description: Cate Le Bon and Tim Presley sound blissfully removed on their second album as a duo, in a quizzical world of their own creation. This one’s best played late at night.

title: am i happy, singing_
label: self-released
description: On this three-track album from Sam Ray’s electronic project, originally recorded in 2014, samples are absent and stillness is the move.

title: Hahaha
label: Exploding in Sound
description: On his first album for Exploding in Sound, this son of Palestinian refugees takes his humanistic blues-folk in a more energetic direction.

title: I, Jonathan
label: Rounder
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the highlight of Jonathan Richman’s rich and varied solo career.

title: Boxer (Live in Brussels)
label: 4AD
description: In 2017, the National revisited their 2007 classic Boxer at a show in Brussels, and the set has been packaged for a Record Store Day release. You had to be there...

title: Bless Yo Trap
label: Alamo
description: Lil Pump’s wingman goes through the motions on an aimless, half-baked new 10-song mixtape with “Nice for What” producer Murda Beatz.

title: When I Think of You in a Castle
label: Polyvinyl
description: This Chicago six-piece plays heavy, proggy psychedelic rock with just the right amount of power-pop sugar to sweeten the mix.

title: Inter-Fusion
label: Cleopatra
description: The L.A. psych-soul artist’s first album in more than 40 years is a plodding, overdriven blues-jazz odyssey that feels like a chore.

title: Beautiful Thing
label: Domino
description: Hot Chip’s singer sounds caught in an irresistible haze on his latest solo LP, making music that’s more deluxe than usual but far scruffier than his main band.

title: Addendum
label: Ribbon Music
description: Presented as a companion piece to last year’s Screen Memories, John Maus’ latest captures the avant-garde artist at his most irreverent and unguarded.

title: ruiner
label: Fueled by Ramen
description: The second album from the promising emo-rap project of Joe Mulherin is sometimes potent, but it buckles from a lack of conviction.

title: Remains
label: Silence
description: Across two studio albums and three discs of unreleased live material, the late-1960s Swedish free-music collective goes in hard on repetitive, mind-expanding psychedelic jams.

title: BC35: The 35 Year Anniversary of BC Studio
label: Bronson
description: This live document from 2016 gathers members of Swans, Sonic Youth, and other underground vets to pay tribute to Martin Bisi, the iconic producer whose touch defined the sound of New York noise.

title: Selectors 005
label: Dekmantel
description: The German DJ offers a spellbinding summary of her sound with this compilation of slow, ominous machine grooves. It’s a cross-section of her record collection, but also a map of a community.

title: The ArtScience Remixes EP
label: Blue Note
description: This remix set, based on Glasper’s 2016 album, moves with the freewheeling rhythm of a beat tape. It’s a low-stakes but very fun session.

title: Gada
label: LuckyMe
description: The debut tape from the Montreal vocalist and producer is a daring, eclectic mix of experimental R&B, where intoxicated club nights bleed into sunglasses-and-Advil mornings.

title: Joyride
label: RCA
description: The long-delayed second album from Tinashe includes a handful of bulletproof bops but has arrived as a fragmented vision of the popstar’s many talents.

title: Dimensional People
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Mouse on Mars’ latest is a 43-minute suite broken up by short movements featuring a wide array of guests. The duo’s try-anything spirit remains embedded in every note.

title: Aphelion EP
label: Brainfeeder
description: In the big leagues now, one of the architects of lo-fi house tries to class up his goofy name with a four-track EP and a high-def vision.

title: A Girl Cried Red
label: Rough Trade
description: The latest mixtape from Destiny Frasqueri pulls from her love of emo and alt-rock. It’s an underdeveloped but strangely addictive left-turn.

title: Song for Alpha
label: Phantasy
description: Turning away from the mix of big-room energy and outré sounds that marked his debut, the London producer’s surprisingly muted second album is a catch-all for his varied tastes.

title: Roxy - Tonight’s the Night Live
label: Reprise
description: In 1973, Neil Young played the inaugural show at the Los Angeles club, The Roxy. The reissued recording captures a night that turned his famously bracing album into something warmer and vibrant.

title: Let Night Come on Bells End the Day
label: Recital Program
description: Using Mellotron and electric organ, the Canadian minimalist teases echoes of Baroque music and post-rock while honing in on the idea of the drone as a phenomenological, time-bending experience.

title: Capture the Flag
label: Bridge Nine
description: On their second album, they're not so much raging against the machine as blazing through the air that keeps it alive.

title: The Underdog
label: Spinning Top
description: The latest from Tame Impala and Pond’s Jay Watson smooths out the pastiche psych-rock and dials down the eccentricity to create a more seamless song cycle.

title: The Other
label: Sub Pop
description: Kyle Thomas’ fifth album as King Tuff is more fleshed out and lustrous than before, now preoccupied with death, environmental degradation, and technological dependency.

title: Cerebral Hemispheres
label: Alleviated
description: On the first full-length Mr. Fingers album in almost 25 years, Larry Heard attempts to sum up the full range of his interests and talents.

title: Fragmentos EP
label: Mixpak
description: Leaving the grand maximalism of his previous releases behind, the UK producer focuses more on the comedown of heartbreak creating an altogether cathartic dancefloor experience.

title: Challenge Me Foolish
label: Planet Mu
description: Following two previous archival collections, Challenge Me Foolish dusts off unreleased tracks from the late 1990s, when the Planet Mu founder was making breakbeat-laced IDM with a strange sense of humor.

title: The Marshall Mathers LP
label: Aftermath
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we explore Eminem’s monumental album The Marshall Mathers LP.

title: Songs for Midi EP
label: Warp
description: The London producer’s new instrumental EP is off-kilter, mercurial, and playful, at once a logical extension and a radical departure from his previous work.

title: Connected and Respected
label: Heavy on the Grind
description: E-40 sounds like a resigned elder statesman on his fourth album with cousin B-Legit, and that’s a surprise coming from someone who used to be superhuman.

title: The Invisible Comes to Us
label: Smithsonian Folkways
description: These folklorists and singers take an audacious step forward on album three, subtly pushing at what folk music sounds like and what it can do.

title: Johnny Cash: Forever Words
label: Legacy
description: Cash family and friends, plus Kacey Musgraves, Chris Cornell, Robert Glasper and others, make songs out of the late Man in Black’s poetry.

title: Pinned
label: Dead Oceans
description: The noise-rock band’s fifth album features new voices, new textures, but strikes the same affected pose.

title: Tree of Forgiveness
label: Oh Boy
description: The songwriter’s first album of new music in 13 years is wise and economical. At 71, John Prine is a virtuoso at understatement, finding the joy in the mundane, and writing about what it means to be alive.

title: The Deconstruction
label: E Works
description: On Eels’ 12th album, Mark Everett trots out his reflexive self-loathing and elementary rhyme schemes one more time, with no clear reason why.

title: Personne d’autre
label: Parlophone
description: Her first album since 2012 is a reflective, characteristically elegant session, surveying the singer’s advancing years in calm repose.

title: Universal Love: Wedding Songs Reimagined EP
label: Sony
description: Featuring Bob Dylan, St. Vincent, and Ben Gibbard, the performances here breathe refreshing gay life into old songs, even if it smacks of branded content a little bit.

title: H
label: The Artist
description: Split between hedonism and hardened street anthems, the Mob Figaz rapper’s first album in more than a decade feels like a time capsule of Bay Area hip-hop as it used to be.

title: CARE FOR ME
label: Saba Pivot
description: The grief-stricken Chicago rapper’s latest is a marvel of craft, musicality, and emotion. Through Saba’s inner turmoil, he finds his most powerful and diaristic storytelling.

title: Where We Were Together
label: Damnably
description: These South Korean devotees of the ’90s indie-rock canon make delicate, bruising music about indecision and loneliness (and lots of drinking).

title: Private Stock
label: Sav Cav Music
description: The New Orleans rapper’s latest album is a meditation on the gravest, most tranquil parts of modern American life, marked by moments of trauma and ones of tranquility. Quelle Chris guests on two key tracks.

title: Geography
label: Beyond The Groove
description: The British singer and beatmaker’s largely self-produced debut album is a pleasant, frictionless listen that benefits from his obvious chops but is held back by his risk-averse tendencies.

title: Total Xanarchy
label: Columbia
description: On his debut album, the standard-bearer of the sad-rap movement refuses to reveal much in the way of emotion at all, aside from a kind of sullen, conflicted defiance.

title: Isolation
label: Virgin EMI
description: The debut album from the Colombian-American singer is a world of her own. Her wide range pulls in sounds from reggaetón, funk, and R&B and positions her to become a new gravitational force in pop.

title: Bellowing Sun
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: Jaime Fennelly assembles a full-band and a grand vision for his sixth album as Mind Over Mirrors, a complex and beautiful synth-and-drone time warp.

title: Invasion of Privacy
label: Atlantic
description: Cardi B’s remarkable debut places her, without a doubt, in the pantheon of great rappers. It is both brazen and vulnerable, filled with wild amounts of personality, style, and craft.

title: Loud Patterns
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The first full-length album from the British songwriter and producer Kyle Molleson is dark and dissonant, electronic rock that captures the thrum of cities and the solitude of the country.

title: There’s Always More at the Store EP
label: Technicolour
description: The Canadian producer takes steps toward stripping down his laid-back house sound, but the rosy glow of his previous releases remains.

title: Vacation in Hell
label: Glorious Dead
description: The second studio album from the staunchly insular Brooklyn rap trio is streamlined and crisp, carried by a newfound momentum missing on their debut.

title: Sex & Food
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Ruban Nielson’s mildew-covered fourth record continues UMO’s long journey inward, pinballing between love and indifference, bops and dirges, pop and its opposite.

title: Goat Girl
label: Rough Trade
description: The debut LP from this South London band is absurd, playful, and more than a little unsettling, sounding at times like a less romantic Libertines.

title: The World Is Yours
label: Interscope
description: The young Atlanta rapper argues that he’s made it, but his pro forma trap debut suggests that he’s not quite there yet.

title: Sextape
label: self-released
description: Cameron Mesirow’s intimate new project builds her production around conversations about formative sexual experiences, which run the gamut from humorous to disturbing, and are often both at once.

title: American Recordings
label: American Recordings
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we explore Johnny Cash’s 1994 comeback American Recordings.

title: You Fucken Sucker
label: Temporary Residence
description: The Books member returns to familiar terrain, but his drifting electronic mood pieces are too often riddled with diaristic scribblings and nihilistic asides that keep the listener at arm’s length.

title: Pain & Pleasure EP
label: Machine Entertainment Group
description: Tink’s first release since leaving Timbaland’s label is a declaration of freedom that leans away from the personal touch of her best work.

title: Hellbender
label: Relapse
description: One of the most underappreciated bands in American rock’n’roll returns after 14 years, still playing as raw, fast, and loud as ever.

title: Moosebumps: An Exploration Into Modern Day Horripilation
label: Bulk
description: With some modern flourishes, Kool Keith, Dan the Automator, and DJ QBert reconvene mostly for a boom-bap throwback to the ill and the grotesque style of their first 1996 outing.

title: Bark Your Head Off, Dog
label: Saddle Creek
description: Led by singer Frances Quinlan and her remarkable songcraft, the Philly band’s third album is warm and spacious, filled with rich stories rendered beautifully in the abstract.

title: The Louder I Call, the Faster It Runs
label: Merge
description: Recording in the duo’s respective hometowns yields Wye Oak’s brightest, most straightforward effort yet, in which the limits of human understanding are a source of fascination, not frustration.

title: Golden
label: BMG
description: You’ve heard sophisti-Kylie, disco Kylie, and Kraftwerk Kylie. On her 14th album, she tries on a new costume: Ready or not, here comes country Kylie.

title: I Don’t Run
label: Mom & Pop
description: The Spanish group’s second album displays the superior songcraft of the band, as vocalists Ana Perrote and Carlotta Cosials wade through love’s messy feelings with confidence and exuberance.

title: Sister Cities
label: Hopeless
description: On their sixth album, the Springsteen of Philly pop-punk and his bandmates look to the world outside their hometown.

title: Virtue
label: Cult
description: The second album from Julian Casablancas and his motley New York band is sludgy, psychedelic sesh that occasionally coheres into surprising moments of clarity and radiance.

title: Liberating Guilt and Fear
label: Get Better
description: The Philadelphia noise-rock band’s new tape is a thrilling rush of punk violence, pop sparkle, art-rock experimentalism—and wild chirping bird noises.

title: Just Cause Y’all Waited
label: Only the Family
description: This mixtape, released after Durk’s departure from Def Jam, is a minor but effective dispatch from one of Chicago’s most compelling narrators.

title: Chris Carter’s Chemistry Lessons Volume One
label: Mute
description: The onetime industrial futurist, formerly of Throbbing Gristle, casts a backward glance at 1960s electronics and British folk, weaving cut-up voices into a curious shape that floats outside time.

title: Daphne & Celeste Save The World
label: Balatonic
description: The Y2K-era bubblegum-pop duo team up with Max Tundra for a fun, ambitious, downright bizarre comeback album, their first LP since 2000.

title: Haze
label: Big Crown
description: Three musicians in their early twenties draw on the hedonistic rock'n'roll blueprint of the 1960s and 1970s on their beautiful, dazed debut LP.

title: Everything’s Fine
label: Mello Music Group
description: Part biting satire, part cognitive behavioral therapy, Jean Grae and Quelle Chris’ collaboration is a hilarious, caustic, and gorgeous consideration of what it really means to be “fine” today.

title: NON Worldwide Compilation Trilogy Volume 2: Part 1
label: NON Worldwide
description: In the first part of an ambitious compilation, the NON Worldwide label surveys club music’s avant-garde while confronting hegemonic power structures.

title: Liberty
label: Shadowbox Music
description: On her seventh LP, the Canadian country singer spins a wild, Spaghetti Western-style yarn about heartbreak, revenge, and redemption.

title: Uneven Paths: Deviant Pop From Europe 1980-1991
label: Music From Memory
description: The widespread dissemination of punk’s DIY ethos coincided with an explosion of affordable studio technology, leading to a largely unheralded revolution in home-recorded pop.

title: Warm Bodies
label: Lumpy
description: Olivia Gibb’s messy, experimental garage rock sounds unhinged and strangely human on Warm Bodies’ debut. Come for the unnerving body horror, stay for the fiery guitar solos.

title: My Dear Melancholy,
label: XO
description: The Weeknd’s new six-song EP finds him in limbo between the bleary-eyed vibe of his early mixtapes and the bulletproof pop stylings of his last two albums.

title: The Calling EP
label: Twisted Elegance
description: Following last year’s debut album, the Dutch-Iranian singer continues to mine trip-hop for inspiration, with a voice that evokes the genre’s greats.

title: Czarface Meets Metal Face
label: Get on Down
description: This comic-book crossover between MF DOOM, Wu-Tang’s Inspectah Deck, and Boston duo 7L & Esoteric attempts to evoke the heyday of underground rap, with mixed results.

title: Golden Hour
label: MCA Nashville
description: The mystical grandeur of Golden Hour creates a magnetic effect as Kacey Musgraves sings simply about the world as if she’s the first person to notice, and you’re the first one she’s telling.

title: Expectations
label: EMPIRE
description: Hayley Kiyoko’s ambitious debut is at its best when it’s barbed and confrontational, but the former Disney star is still trying to hone her budding pop star identity.

title: Raw Like Sushi
label: Virgin
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we explore Neneh Cherry’s explosive pop debut, Raw Like Sushi.

title: Shake It Up / Heartbeat City
label: Rhino
description: Two new reissues of the group’s early-1980s albums capture a band at the intersection of AOR and power pop for whom precision was everything.

title: Ceremony of Dreams: Studio Sessions & Outtakes, 1972-1977
label: Tompkins Square
description: The unearthing of these odd compositions from the East Coast ambient group creates a three-hour stream of instrumental riches, whether you’re looking to find samples or get lost in a trance.

title: The Messthetics
label: Dischord
description: Bassist Joe Lally and drummer Brendan Canty—the rhythm section of Fugazi—team up with experimental D.C. guitarist Anthony Pirog for an economic, emotionally resonant instrumental power-trio record.

title: No Joy / Sonic Boom EP
label: Joyful Noise
description: The Canadian shoegaze band’s singer teams up with Spaceman 3’s Pete Kember in an attempt to push past their comfort zone into electronic territory.

title: Code Girl
label: Firehouse 12
description: Writing for a five-person group with vocalist Amirtha Kidambi at its center, the composer-guitarist finds fresh inspiration slipping between diverse genres and songwriting modes.

title: Freedom
label: Sacred Bones
description: The fifth album from Damon McMahon is his euphoric breakthrough. Everything feels silvery and romantic, like a hallucination of the classic-rock songbook.

title: Your Queen Is a Reptile
label: Impulse!
description: On this London group’s first LP for Impulse!, saxophonist Shabaka Hutchings uses jazz’s cultural memory as a rich language that informs an entirely new conversation.

title: Collection 1
label: Godd ComplexX
description: The solo debut from this rapper and singer, who’s worked with Usher and Jidenna, unfolds like a shamelessly wild night out, with material highs and emotional lows galore.

title: Gravitational Pull vs. the Desire for an Aquatic Life
label: Kranky
description: The 1996 album, newly reissued, finds the drone duo transitioning from their rough-hewn early phase into a more graceful, wordlessly evocative mode.

title: The Rite of May EP
label: NUXXE
description: MaryLou Mayniel’s latest collection of hazy R&B is full of dewy vocal passages rendered cool and distant by heavy processing that lands in the safe space between accessible and experimental.

title: Vessel
label: Sub Pop
description: On Greta Kline’s third official album, pure love, self-loathing, and taxidermied dogs all find their way into her dazzling world of perennially inspired indie pop.

title: Don Talk
label: Atlantic
description: The Bronx rapper’s latest project reveals little about his persona other than his approach to rapping, which is blunt and functional.

title: Sex & Cigarettes
label: Def Jam
description: The queen of the coy R&B ballad returns for her first solo album in nearly a decade, making only a few concessions to contemporary trends.

title: Edgewood
label: Ear Drummer
description: Newly signed to Mike WiLL’s label, the Atlanta rapper offers an unsparing chronicle of his come-up on this smoky, sinister major-label debut.

title: Paradox (Original Music From the Film)
label: Reprise
description: The soundtrack to this largely incoherent film achieves a shaky sense of grace thanks to the dusty music from Neil Young and his backing band, Promise of the Real.

title: The Four Worlds
label: Warp
description: Stepping back from the clubbier styles he’s best known for, the prolific electronic polymath turns his attentions to a moody ambient album that shows remarkable restraint.

title: Isle of Dogs (Original Soundtrack)
label: ABKCO
description: The soundtrack to Wes Anderson’s new stop-motion film, built around Alexandre Desplat’s instrumental score, embodies the movie’s spirit of cherishing rather than fearing difference.

title: Blueprint
label: Don Giovanni
description: On her second solo album, the trailblazing punk and Chicana icon sketches a new route forward from her 1970s roots.

title: The Kids Are Alright
label: Parkwood
description: The Beyoncé-approved sister act are fearless on their debut album, reshaping pop and R&B in their own images until even the highest-profile co-signs seem beside the point.

title: 01DEAS
label: R&S
description: Ayman Rostom’s debut album under his house music alias covers a surprisingly large amount of ground with lumbering grooves, off-kilter rhythms, and impish sample play.

title: The Final Tour: The Bootleg Series, Vol. 6
label: Columbia Legacy
description: The audible friction between Davis and Coltrane on almost every number of this four-disc set makes for a fascinating listen, a live document of two players undergoing tectonic shifts in their style.

title: Cinema
label: Grönland
description: Less than a year after the Can co-founder’s death, this generous box set lights a path through his sprawling catalog and confirms both his genius and his prescience.

title: Twentytwo in Blue
label: Mom & Pop
description: The Brooklyn band’s second album offers a reverent spin on the alt and indie-rock canon. Their songwriting has grown tighter since their debut, but their music is unlikely to inspire strong emotions.

title: California EP
label: Mad Decent
description: Plot twist: Diplo’s star-studded new EP will not make you twerk, but it might make you cry.

title: 2 Tone
label: Birdwatcher Records
description: The avant-garde composer and the tabla master orchestrate a controlled collision of their approaches, with harmonious results.

title: Something Else
label: Pye
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we explore the Kinks’ wistful 1967 classic Something Else.

title: The Asylum Era
label: Anti-
description: These first seven albums constitute the first act of Waits’ remarkable career, even as these reissues complicate that journey from assembly-line singer-songwriter to eclectic iconoclast.

title: Deep Soundscapes
label: Love Potion
description: Active since the 1990s, the Japanese producer is enjoying a rising profile in the West. His dreamy new album celebrates the synergy between humans and machines.

title: Hormone Lemonade
label: Duophonic
description: Jamming and overdubbing on top of band member Holger Zapf’s experiments with self-constructed drum machines, Cavern of Anti-Matter deliver their most rhythmically intensive record yet.

title: Cardamom Garden EP
label: Modern Sky Entertainment
description: Delving deeper into their lead singer’s Iranian-American roots, the band melds Farsi lyrics with shades of the Beach Boys and the Shangri-Las.

title: Boarding House Reach
label: Third Man
description: With the joy and wit all but absent from his songwriting, Jack White’s third solo album becomes a long, bewildering slog.

title: The Smoke
label: self-released
description: With chintzy synths and cryptic lyrics, the artist formerly known as Inga Copeland challenges deep-seated assumptions about musical taste and emotive songcraft.

title: Longwave
label: Woodsist
description: The Detroit band brings a light touch to the melancholic alt-country songs on this album, which emerged from a spontaneous session in the woods.

title: Music and Poetry of the Kesh
label: Freedom to Spend
description: In 1985, the esteemed novelist worked with composer Todd Barton to create an album of unheard language and instruments. The reissue highlights the rich, totally immersive art Ursula K. Le Guin sought to create.

title: New Material
label: Jagjaguwar
description: The band’s third full-length is an easier and more melodic entry into their spindly post-punk. Here, their defeatism takes on a new tenor: battle-worn, sincere, and not quite so antagonistic.

title: Elevators: Act I & II
label: Nehruvia LLC
description: The New York rapper reunites with his prodigal mentor, MF DOOM, and forges a new partnership with Kaytranada on his full-length solo debut.

title: PRhyme 2
label: PRhyme
description: On his second LP as a duo with DJ Premier, Royce 5’9” fights mightily to offer more than corny punchlines and pointless bars.

title: Brat Mail
label: Republic
description: Kash Doll’s short, 22-minute album contains a lot of flex, some humility, but feels like a victory lap run before the official race has even started.

title: Rich as in Spirit
label: Motown
description: Quan’s official debut is a triumph of willpower and talent, a detail-oriented collection with immaculate production that rightfully reestablishes his place in rap.

title: No Fool Like an Old Fool
label: Western Vinyl
description: From its muted-color harmonies to its overly padded beats, much of Caroline Sallee’s witty and beautiful second album sounds like it’s trying to hide in plain sight

title: High Maintenance EP
label: Warner Bros.
description: The “ICY GRL” rapper’s debut EP is a low-stakes but gratifying listen, full of witty one-liners and cheeky quotables.

title: A Strange Journey Into the Unimaginable
label: Strange Music
description: The veteran rapper’s latest includes a harrowing look at his personal life buoyed by some lighthearted, throwback fare.

title: Bliss
label: GTR
description: Touching on a variety of extreme-music styles, and sampling from iconic revolutionary thinkers, the Philadelphia grindcore quartet grafts noise onto bull-headed hardcore, to blistering effect.

title: Dog Bless
label: Topshelf
description: One of the last revival-style emo bands standing sings about boredom and getting older on their frankly audacious second album.

title: There’s a Riot Going On
label: Matador
description: Yo La Tengo capture the feeling of post-traumatic calm on their latest album, assuring their status as a wry and comforting cornerstone of indie rock.

title: All That Must Be
label: Domino
description: The UK producer’s second album sounds more ready for the club but features the same neon, wistful, song-centric style as his debut.

title: Consumers Park
label: Nature Sounds
description: The Pro Era lieutenant offers golden-age beats and neighborhood-corner rhymes on his solo debut, with echoes of Biggie Smalls and Phife Dawg.

title: I’ll Be Your Girl
label: Capitol
description: Buoyed by a fresh coat of synths and a streamlined energy, the Decemberists’ latest is a curious middle-of-the-road album, teasing a number of directions without committing to any of them.

title: Long Trax 2
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Long, also known as the ambient artist Celer, uses the static meter of deep house to explore themes of inertia and stasis in dance music, politics, and society.

title: Jericho Sirens
label: Sub Pop
description: Teeming with revved-up riffs and apocalyptic imagery, the post-hardcore group’s first album since 2005 reasserts their status as the most merciless band in their scene.

title: Nebraska
label: Columbia
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we explore the solitary sound of the incomparable Nebraska.

title: Surrender Your Soul
label: Secret Sound Club
description: The Toronto rapper's debut shows off his ridiculously catchy melodies and distinct persona, even as it moves within templates set by his peers.

title: Ventriloquism
label: Naïve
description: Tackling a range of R&B radio hits from the 1980s and 1990s, Meshell Ndegeocello treats the practice of covering another’s songs as an act of intimacy and empathy.

title: The Chocolate Box EP
label: Def Jam
description: Most of the songs on this four-track EP are just fine. One is a boorish, boring misfire that should have stayed in the vault.

title: Romance
label: Joyful Noise
description: The Brooklyn band’s 12th album explores new ground and blossoms within the social, spatial, and economic confines of New York.

title: New Path
label: DFA
description: Inspired by Philip K. Dick’s A Scanner Darkly, the married Montreal duo explore themes of addiction, loss, and identity in cinematically tinged coldwave.

title: The Neighbourhood
label: Columbia
description: The Los Angeles band struggle to find an identity on their third album of dramatic rap-tinged alternative rock.

title: Cocoa Sugar
label: Ninja Tune
description: The latest from the experimental rap trio is chaotic but sleek, a streamlined presentation of the singular style Young Fathers have crafted.

title: Myths 003 EP
label: Mexican Summer
description: The third and best installment of Mexican Summer’s collaborative EP series pairs two soft-focus psychedelic bands to righteous effect.

title: Now Only
label: P.W. Elverum & Sun
description: The expansive companion album to last year’s A Crow Looked At Me is no less a marvel. Phil Elverum’s latest is part memoir and part magnum opus, sung softly and with wonder.

title: The Wolf of Grape Street
label: Alamo
description: The latest collection from the Watts rapper is an essential piece of West Coast rap, at times pulsating and manic, born from a singular writer and chameleonic stylist.

title: Physically Sick 2
label: Allergy Season
description: A wildly diverse range of house and techno artists bring rich colors and unexpected energies to this bail reform fundraising compilation.

title: Communion
label: Mirrorball
description: Blending traditional Korean instruments with woodwinds and mallets, the South Korean composer strikes a captivating balance between minimalism and improvised music.

title: Bobby Tarantino II
label: Def Jam
description: Logic’s latest mixtape is blessedly lighter on its toes and more entertaining than his overambitious albums, doing far more with far less.

title: LONER
label: New West
description: On her self-assured second album, this singer-songwriter uses her mordant wit to confront serious subjects, exorcising trauma with hooks and humor.

title: Francis Trouble
label: Red Bull
description: The guitarist continues his 2010s hot streak with some of the brightest, scrappiest music he’s ever made as a solo artist.

title: You Were Never Really Here (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Lakeshore
description: The prolific composer and Radiohead member crafts a diverse, dissonant, and beat-heavy score that matches the alternate realities of Lynne Ramsay’s psychological thriller.

title: August Greene
label: August Greene, LLC
description: Common teams with Karriem Riggins and Robert Glasper for an album whose best moments suggest a dignified, modern maturation.

title: Have fun EP
label: XL
description: The array of sound and style on the Norwegian duo’s latest EP is engrossing, the sound of off-kilter future-pop composed with equal amounts of sugar and existential dread.

title: Crânio EP
label: Warp
description: For his first release on Warp, the batida and electronic musician puts forth his own meticulous, otherworldly sound and reconnects with the avant-dance spirit of the label’s early years.

title: White Is Relic/Irrealis Mood
label: Polyvinyl
description: Citing influences from DJ Screw to James Baldwin, Kevin Barnes’ latest is a maximalist dance party about our simulated realities.

title: GVVVV
label: CRZKNY
description: An eclectic star of the Japanese beat scene tilts toward the aggressive spirit of gabber and hardcore, largely leaving behind the stylistic markers of footwork.

title: Spiritual Conversations EP
label: Mozzy
description: The Sacramento rapper’s six-song EP brings his themes of psychological trauma to the foreground, suggesting alternate readings of his previous work.

title: Eucalyptus EP
label: Club Chai
description: On their debut EP, and the third release from Oakland’s Club Chai, 8ULENTINA channels breakbeats, synths, and recorded objects into an unusual kind of dancefloor interiority.

title: American Utopia
label: Nonesuch
description: David Byrne’s first true solo album in 14 years is daring and open-hearted. The risks Byrne takes on these songs, however, too often feel clumsy or gaudy.

title: I Need to Start a Garden
label: Mama Bird
description: On her debut LP, the Portland songwriter turns her incisive gaze inward, writing from the feelings in her heart and the visions in her head.

title: Path
label: Terrible
description: The Brooklyn noise musician Will Kraus makes one person sound like a fully staffed shoegaze band, adding new personality to a storied genre.

title: Get Up With It
label: Columbia
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we explore 1974’s black funk dreamscape from Miles Davis.

title: Hunchin’ All Night
label: Rush Hour
description: Hunee, the South Korean-born, Berlin-based DJ gathers a dozen of his favorite dancefloor cuts from across the decades, surveying South African funk, Chicago house, and fusions galore.

title: I’m Bad Now
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: The Nova Scotia quartet’s chilled-out, endearing indie rock gets a slightly more cutting edge on on their third album.

title: Everything Was Beautiful, and Nothing Hurt
label: Little Idiot
description: With a long list of guest vocalists, Moby’s latest more melancholy album is lush but feels anemic and minor compared to some of his best work.

title: Whistle Down the Wind
label: Proper
description: On her first album in a decade, the folk great takes a hard look at the state of the world and tries to muster something like hope.

title: Riddles
label: Carpark
description: The noisy Baltimore post-punk duo team up with Dan Deacon for an album of ’80s pop melodies and newfound lyrical maturity.

title: Lil Boat 2
label: Quality Control
description: A sequel in name only, Yachty’s leaden, rap-heavy album demands that the listener accept Yachty on his terms and shamelessly argues that he can be anything he wants to be.

title: OMGRONNY
label: Independently Popular
description: On his major-label debut, SoundCloud rap architect Ronny J showcases his talents as a producer, songwriter, and rapper, with assists from Denzel Curry, Smokepurpp, and XXXTentacion.

title: Corpse Fortress
label: Relapse
description: The Maryland sludge-doom band’s latest album (and first for Relapse Records) is a downright lethal—and impressively inclusive—listen.

title: GOOD Job, You Found Me EP
label: G.O.O.D. Music
description: The self-taught Chicago polymath follows his own odd muse on his GOOD Music debut, whispering consumerist sweet nothings over sparse, menacing beats.

title: You’re Not Alone
label: Sony
description: On his first album in nine years, the zen party master uses his operatically excessive music to challenge you to give in to positivity and get over yourself.

title: Feeling EP
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Singer and composer Jenny Hval and multi-instrumentalist Håvard Volden collaborate for an EP of two extended, lucid, and intimate pieces of art-punk.

title: Shit Don’t Rhyme No More
label: self-released
description: The latest album from the oblique strategist of New York rap is an urgent attempt to give order, in small increments, to an orderless time.

title: Álbum Desconhecido
label: Príncipe Discos
description: The young, Manchester-based Portuguese producer offers a radical take on batida that draws on the scrappy aggression of UK bass and experimental electro-R&B.

title: Memories Don’t Die
label: Mad Love
description: The Toronto singer and rapper’s second album seeks immortality, but it's just a record full of crude imitations of every remotely bankable contemporary R&B or rap song.

title: RR2: The Bitter Dose
label: Marci Enterprises
description: The Long Island rapper’s latest is a restatement of his core principles, recited in the hallowed style of a religious scripture.

title: How to Socialise & Make Friends
label: Run for Cover
description: The second album from the Australian trio hums with rage and retribution, executed with biting specificity and vast emotional range by singer Georgia Maq.

title: Historian
label: Matador
description: On her second album, the Virginia songwriter doesn’t merely reckon with loss; she tells a story about the way people carry each other through time.

title: American Dollar Bill - Keep Facing Sideways, You’re Too Hideous to Look At Face on
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Former Isis frontman Aaron Turner’s minimal-leaning metal trio takes on a new challenge: Keeping up with Japanese avant-garde pioneer Keiji Haino.

title: A Productive Cough
label: Merge
description: Led by the indomitable Patrick Stickles, the band’s fifth album shifts towards a more stripped down, barroom rock feel. But for all its musical freedom, A Productive Cough is still a laborious record.

title: Black Times
label: Strut
description: On his fourth album with his father’s Egypt 80 ensemble, Seun Kuti delivers a smartly distilled primer on the power of Afrobeat.

title: Record
label: Merge
description: On one of the defining albums of her 38-year career, the Everything But the Girl singer embraces her inner disco maven in pursuit of freedom from society’s ordained roles for women.

title: Still Trippin’
label: Hyperdub
description: Infused with his own rapping, the debut album from Teklife’s youngest member makes a strong case for the way footwork has been strengthened, not diluted, as its form has loosened up.

title: Who Are You
label: Beats in Space
description: L.A. musician Eddie Ruscha’s new synth-music project draws on Balearic beat and ambient pop for a concise, easygoing listen.

title: Drift
label: Sacred Bones
description: After a stressful period of reinvention, the band frolics in greener grass, following its wandering muse wherever it leads.

title: Clean
label: Fat Possum
description: Sophie Allison’s excellent studio debut is a compact album of clear melodies, plainspoken lyrics, and the impossibly tangled logic of infatuation.

title: The Diary
label: Rap-A-Lot
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we explore Scarface’s deathly personal 1994 solo album.

title: Felt
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The latest from the gothic avant-rock band sees the four-piece loosen up and let slip the forces begging for release since their debut.

title: Dreamweapon
label: Superior Viaduct
description: Spacemen 3’s newly reissued drone album—recorded in 1988 in the lobby of a movie theater—marked the start of the curious rise of one of the UK’s most influential indie rock bands.

title: Once EP
label: Ninja Tune
description: The South Korea-born, Berlin-based producer is an expert navigator of the balancing act required to make great house music.

title: Tahoe
label: Kranky
description: Erstwhile hip-hop beatmaker Lee Bannon fully embraces ambient music’s conventions on an album that shifts between placid states and disquiet.

title: Superorganism
label: Domino
description: The debut from the UK collective is a hugely accomplished reflection of the present, a magpie-friendly collage of pop all glued together by the laconic voice of Orono Noguchi.

title: Hexadic III
label: Drag City
description: Six Organs of Admittance’s Ben Chasny invites some friends (members of Mount Moriah, Sunn O))), and more) to help put his arcane guitar theory into thrilling action.

title: Stone Woman EP
label: self-released
description: The Toronto R&B singer’s second EP charts the collapse of a relationship through six downcast tracks.

title: All Nerve
label: 4AD
description: The Breeders’ new album features their iconic Last Splash lineup. It is smoothly confident with many moments of bliss, even as the lyrics evoke isolation, frustration, and scuzz.

title: WWW.
label: American
description: On the Chicago rapper’s latest album, it’s hard to tell whether he is a talented guy who’s just not working hard or a hack with an extraordinary work ethic.

title: Worldwide Angel
label: Puro
description: The Barcelona singer sticks to her synth-heavy, sticky-sweet sound on an album that’s meant to signal her arrival as a global force.

label: Other People
description: Dusting off an old alias, Nicolas Jaar lets loose a surprise release of sample-heavy cuts both bolder and more refined than his early club tracks.

title: This Is Eggland
label: self-released
description: The UK duo’s fifth album, produced by Dave Fridmann, is as good an introduction as you’ll get to their charmingly skewed perspective on the world

title: Time & Space
label: Roadrunner
description: The “experimentation” on the Baltimore band’s latest album is hesitant and unfocused. It’s a punishingly familiar collision of yesteryear's crossover rock with textbook hardcore bluster.

title: Basic Behaviour
label: Arts & Crafts
description: This Toronto band’s best songs have just the right amount of rage to get them out of the shadows of PJ Harvey and Sonic Youth.

title: In Tongues EP
label: 88rising
description: The former YouTube star’s debut album establishes a decent R&B mood but proceeds to wallow in thin, underdeveloped emotions.

title: Smell Smoke
label: Gawk
description: The Boston indie rock band craft a winning, cathartic record about grief, capitalism, and all the stuff we leave behind.

title: async remodels
label: Milan
description: A varied group of remixers tackles the Japanese composer’s 2017 album async, but despite a few standouts, the collection lacks the stark force of the original.

title: Three/Three
label: Ghostly International
description: The Michigan electronic hip-hop producer returns to his best-known project after a decade-plus break. With Danny Brown, MF DOOM, and more.

title: Landfall
label: Nonesuch
description: Laurie Anderson’s collaboration with the San Francisco-based string quartet presents a powerful, elegiac cycle of songs that show how human memory can be stronger than catastrophe.

title: Hundred Acres
label: Jagjaguwar
description: As his solo career gains momentum, the second-most famous member of Bon Iver spends his latest LP meditating on the simple life.

title: FEVER
label: Computer Ugly
description: The Detroit rapper/producer follows up the instrumental The Rebellion Sessions with a solo rap record that confirms him as a serviceable emcee—and a session leader with a sense of purpose.

title: Language
label: Ghostly International
description: Bryndon Cook is a hired gun for Solange, Chairlift, and Blood Orange; his debut album is a slick, colorful foray into retro-futurist funk that’s fueled by his keen sense of style.

title: Lo Moon
label: Columbia
description: The L.A. band behind 2016’s slow-burning single “Loveless” turns in a perilously top-heavy debut album.

title: Gangin
label: SOB X RBE
description: The four-man Bay Area rap crew delivers a breathless, irresistible, and highly defined record that hits your gut and your shoulders at the same time.

title: Witness Marks: The Works of John B. McLemore
label: Dais
description: The posthumous ambient music of the mercurial genius featured on “S-Town” is a peek into the sounds of his quiet and fascinating life.

title: 40oz. to Freedom
label: Skunk
description: The debut album from the SoCal trio is a flawed artifact of ’90s alt-rock, punk, ska, and hip-hop, but remains a fascinating document of Bradley Nowell as the honey-voiced musical tourist bro.

title: Lala Belu
label: Awesome Tapes From Africa
description: The Ethiopian keyboard maestro’s first new album in two decades radically updates a style that already sounded like the future.

title: Victory Lap
label: All Money In
description: The long-awaited debut from the Los Angeles rapper cashes in on its promise. It’s the most gripping record in his catalog.

title: Gemini II
label: Spirit House
description: Warren’s complex, unwinding melodies shine on her latest album, and while the concept views love through an astrological lens, the lyrics expose life’s crushing banality.

title: Game Winner EP
label: Secretly Canadian
description: This L.A. funk and soul musician, known as a member of Vulfpeck, meanders through a handful of solo joints about love and basketball.

title: 2 Heartless
label: N-Less
description: A revelation hidden in plain sight, this Memphis rapper’s latest project is more proof that he’s headed for bigger things.

title: Kyoto
label: Last Kings
description: The Los Angeles rapper’s latest career move is a pleading, quasi-introspective R&B album that suffers from an almost total lack of imagination.

title: Reachin’ (A New Refutation of Time and Space)
label: Light in the Attic
description: The jazz rap trio’s 1993 debut questions the very fabric of our existence while celebrating its nuances.

title: All at Once
label: Don Giovanni
description: The New Jersey band’s seventh album tilts toward pop-punk, modern rock, and more, with a guest turn from Fugazi’s Brendan Canty.

title: Heart Break Kodak
label: Atlantic
description: On his so-called R&B album, it’s exceedingly difficult to square the real-life allegations of the Florida rapper with the toxic content of his songs.

title: Black Panther (Original Score)
label: Marvel Music
description: Ludwig Göransson’s spectacular score captures the multiplicity of the fictional nation of Wakanda.

title: Loma
label: Sub Pop
description: Shearwater’s Jonathan Meiburg teams up with the duo Cross Record on a slowcore-influenced album enlivened by a surprising musical chemistry.

title: American Nightmare
label: Rise
description: The prodigal trailblazers of Boston hardcore have reunited, returned, and evolved with their first album in 15 years.

title: Last Night All My Dreams Came True
label: Domino Documents
description: Wild Beasts bid fans farewell by revisiting their catalog in a collection of live studio takes. It’s not an entirely satisfying goodbye, but it’s a faithful snapshot of a band always in motion.

title: How to Solve Our Human Problems, Pt. 3
label: Matador
description: After brushes with extroversion, the final installment of their EP series finds singers Sarah Martin and Stuart Murdoch turning inward with songs that take you inside its characters’ private lives.

title: Everything Is Recorded by Richard Russell
label: XL
description: The new project from the head of XL Recordings features collaborations with Sampha, Kamasi Washington, and Ghostface Killah’s son.

title: What a Time to Be Alive
label: Merge
description: More powerful and focused than any of their recent records, the 11th Superchunk album is finally the one that feels genuinely urgent, both of a particular moment and built to outlast it.

title: Bulletproof Luh
label: Bad Taste
description: The Newark rapper is as cold and calculating with people as he is with his money. Everything’s an asset or a liability, no in between.
